questions.question_text:
On which date did the Constitution of India come into effect, establishing India as a Sovereign Democratic Republic?
A. 15th August 1947
B. 26th November 1949
C. 26th January 1950
D. 9th December 1946
questions.model_answer_text: C. 26th January 1950

answer_key.logic_explanation: The chapter explicitly states, 'The Constitution of India came into effect on 26th January 1950, when India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic.' Option A is the date of independence, Option B is the date of adoption, and Option D is the date of the first Constituent Assembly meeting.

questions.question_text:
Which British mission in 1946 put forward the proposal to set up a Constituent Assembly for framing the Indian Constitution?
A. The Cripps Mission
B. The Simon Commission
C. The Cabinet Mission
D. The Wavell Plan
questions.model_answer_text: C. The Cabinet Mission

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text states, '...the Cabinet Mission arrived in India in 1946 and put forward a set of proposals... One of these proposals involved setting up of a Constituent Assembly...'

questions.question_text:
Who was elected as the permanent President of the Constituent Assembly on December 11, 1946?
A. Dr. Sachidananda Sinha
B. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
C. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru
D. Dr. Rajendra Prasad
questions.model_answer_text: D. Dr. Rajendra Prasad

answer_key.logic_explanation: The chapter clearly mentions, 'On December 11, 1946 Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected President of the Constituent Assembly.' Dr. Sachidananda Sinha was the temporary president for the first meeting.

questions.question_text:
According to the provided text, who among the following represented the Anglo-Indian community in the Constituent Assembly?
A. Dr. H.P. Modi
B. Sardar Hukum Singh
C. Mr. Frank Anthony
D. Dr. H.C. Mukherjee
questions.model_answer_text: C. Mr. Frank Anthony

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text explicitly lists the representatives: 'The Anglo-Indians were represented by Mr. Frank Anthony and Mr. S.H. Prater.' The other options represented other communities: Dr. H.P. Modi (Parsees), Sardar Hukum Singh (Sikhs), and Dr. H.C. Mukherjee (Indian Christians).

questions.question_text:
Who proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' in the Constituent Assembly on December 13, 1946, which laid down the 'national goals'?
A. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
B. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru
C. Dr. Rajendra Prasad
D. Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel
questions.model_answer_text: B. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru

answer_key.logic_explanation: The chapter states, 'When the Constituent Assembly started the work of drafting the Constitution, Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' on December 13, 1946.'

questions.question_text:
Who was appointed as the Chairman of the Drafting Committee on August 29, 1947?
A. C. Rajagopalachari
B. Dr. Rajendra Prasad
C. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
D. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru
questions.model_answer_text: C. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text states, 'The Drafting Committee, under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was set up on August 29, 1947 and was entrusted with the task of drafting the Constitution.'

questions.question_text:
On what date was the Constitution of India finally passed and adopted by the Constituent Assembly?
A. 26th January 1950
B. 15th August 1947
C. 29th August 1947
D. 26th November 1949
questions.model_answer_text: D. 26th November 1949

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text says, 'The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949.' This is distinct from the date it came into force (Jan 26, 1950).

questions.question_text:
The date January 26 was chosen for the enforcement of the Constitution because it commemorated which significant historical event from the freedom struggle?
A. The launch of the Quit India Movement
B. The Dandi March
C. The arrival of the Cabinet Mission
D. The declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' at the Lahore Session
questions.model_answer_text: D. The declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' at the Lahore Session

answer_key.logic_explanation: The chapter's section on the 'Significance of January 26' explains that 'At the Lahore Session of the Congress held in December 1929, a resolution was passed which declared Poorna Swaraj or Complete Independence to be the objective of the Congress. January 26, 1930 was fixed as the first Independence Day...'

keywords: D. The declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' at the Lahore Session

questions.question_text:
Which of the following statements best describes the primary function of a Constitution as outlined in the provided text?
A. It exclusively lists the duties of citizens and restrains their actions.
B. It outlines the process for electing a monarch or a dictator.
C. It regulates the powers of the legislative, executive, and judiciary, and protects citizens from arbitrary government decisions.
D. It serves as a historical document detailing the proposals of the Cabinet Mission.
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text states that the Constitution 'regulates the position and powers of the three organs of the governmentâ€”the legislative, the executive and the judiciary' and 'protects the interests of the citizens by restraining the government from taking arbitrary decisions.' Option C accurately summarises these key functions.

questions.question_text:
According to the proposals of the Cabinet Mission of 1946, how were the members of the Constituent Assembly for British India provinces to be chosen?
A. They were to be directly elected by all adult citizens.
B. They were to be nominated by the British Viceroy.
C. They were to be elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies.
D. They were to be appointed by the leaders of the Indian National Congress.
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text explicitly states that one of the proposals of the Cabinet Mission involved 'setting up of a Constituent Assembly whose members were to be elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies (Lower House only).'

questions.question_text:
Following the boycott by the Muslim League and the subsequent partition, the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India was reduced. What was the final membership count compared to the original?
A. Reduced from 389 to 284
B. Reduced from 389 to 299
C. Reduced from 299 to 284
D. Reduced from 395 to 299
questions.model_answer_text: B

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text specifies that 'the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India stood at 299 against the original number of 389 members.' The number 284 refers to the members actually present to sign the final document, not the total membership.

questions.question_text:
The 'Objectives Resolution', which laid down the national goals for the Constitution, was proposed by whom and on what date?
A. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar on August 29, 1947
B. Dr. Rajendra Prasad on December 11, 1946
C. Dr. Sachidananda Sinha on December 9, 1946
D. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946
questions.model_answer_text: D

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text clearly states, 'When the Constituent Assembly started the work of drafting the Constitution, Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' on December 13, 1946.'

questions.question_text:
Which of the following committees was set up on August 29, 1947, and entrusted with the primary task of preparing the draft of the Constitution?
A. The Objectives Committee
B. The Cabinet Mission
C. The Drafting Committee
D. The Union Powers Committee
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text specifies that 'The Drafting Committee, under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was set up on August 29, 1947 and was entrusted with the task of drafting the Constitution.'

questions.question_text:
According to the text, what was the purpose of incorporating the principle of a 'strong Centre', single citizenship, and single judiciary in the Constitution, as advocated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar?
A. To give more power to the Princely States.
B. To limit the Fundamental Rights of the citizens.
C. To maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline.
D. To ensure the government could be easily overthrown.
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text states that Dr. Ambedkar proposed these features to 'integrate Indian society' and therefore 'proposed a strong Centre to maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline.'

questions.question_text:
The Constituent Assembly held three readings of the draft Constitution. On which date was the third and final reading completed, which also marked the adoption of the Constitution?
A. October 17, 1949
B. November 4, 1948
C. January 26, 1950
D. November 26, 1949
questions.model_answer_text: D

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text mentions the timeline of the readings and states, 'It was followed by the third and the final Reading which were completed on November 26, 1949.' It further clarifies that 'The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949.'

questions.question_text:
While the Constitution as a whole came into force on January 26, 1950, some clauses were enforced immediately after its adoption on November 26, 1949. Which of the following is mentioned as a key area covered by these immediately enforced clauses?
A. Fundamental Rights
B. Directive Principles of State Policy
C. Citizenship
D. The election of the President
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text explicitly states, 'After the signing of the Constitution, only the clauses relating to citizenship and some others came into force immediately. This was to enable persons displaced as a result of the partition, to register themselves as Indian citizens.'

questions.question_text:
Who took over as the President of the Indian Union when the Constitution came into effect on January 26, 1950?
A. C. Rajagopalachari
B. Lord Mountbatten
C. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru
D. Dr. Rajendra Prasad
questions.model_answer_text: D

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text states that 'Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who was the President of the Constituent Assembly took over as the President of the Indian Union.' C. Rajagopalachari was the Governor-General.

questions.question_text:
The date January 26 was chosen for the commencement of the Constitution due to its historical importance. This importance is linked to which event from the freedom struggle?
A. The arrival of the Cabinet Mission in 1946.
B. The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly.
C. The resolution for Poorna Swaraj at the Lahore Session of 1929.
D. The passing of the Indian Independence Act in 1947.
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text explains that the date was selected because 'At the Lahore Session of the Congress held in December 1929, a resolution was passed which declared Poorna Swaraj or Complete Independence to be the objective of the Congress. January 26, 1930 was fixed as the first Independence Day.'

questions.question_text: The Constituent Assembly of undivided India originally consisted of 389 members. What was the final membership after the withdrawal of members representing territories that went to Pakistan, and how many members were actually present to sign the Constitution on November 26, 1949?
questions.model_answer_text: B

options.label: A
options.text: 389 members; 299 signed.

options.label: B
options.text: 299 members; 284 signed.

options.label: C
options.text: 299 members; all 299 signed.

options.label: D
options.text: 389 members; 284 signed.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The provided text states that after the Muslim League boycotted the Assembly and members from Pakistani territories withdrew, 'the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India stood at 299 against the original number of 389 members.' It further specifies that 'Of these, 284 were actually present on November 26, 1949, and appended their signatures to the Constitution as finally passed.' Therefore, option B correctly identifies both figures.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was NOT an objective laid down in the 'Objectives Resolution' proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946?
questions.model_answer_text: B

options.label: A
options.text: The guarantee of social, political, and economic democracy to all people.

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of a strong Centre with a single judiciary.

options.label: C
options.text: The safeguarding of the rights of minorities and backward classes.

options.label: D
options.text: The granting of Fundamental Rights to all citizens.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text lists four key points of the 'Objectives Resolution': 1. India will be a 'republic', 2. Ideals of social, political and economic democracy, 3. Granting of Fundamental Rights, and 4. Safeguarding rights of minorities. The principle of a 'strong Centre' and 'single judiciary' is mentioned separately under the section on Dr. Ambedkar's contributions to integrate Indian society, not as part of the initial Objectives Resolution.

questions.question_text: According to the provided text, which constitutional principle was incorporated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar specifically to ensure that the Fundamental Rights of individuals are not infringed upon by the Centre or State governments?
questions.model_answer_text: D

options.label: A
options.text: The system of reservation of jobs for Scheduled Castes and Tribes.

options.label: B
options.text: The incorporation of Directive Principles of State Policy.

options.label: C
options.text: The provision of a single, uniform citizenship.

options.label: D
options.text: The inclusion of the Right to Constitutional Remedies.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text explicitly states under Dr. Ambedkar's contributions that he 'Incorporated the Right to Constitutional Remedies to ensure that the Fundamental Rights of the individuals are not infringed by the Centre or the State governments.' While the other options are also his contributions, they serve different primary purposes: reservation for social justice, Directive Principles for social/economic democracy, and single citizenship for national integrity.

questions.question_text: The Constitution of India was adopted on November 26, 1949, but came into force on January 26, 1950. What is the historical significance of the date January 26th that led to its selection?
questions.model_answer_text: B

options.label: A
options.text: It was the day the Drafting Committee under Dr. Ambedkar was set up.

options.label: B
options.text: It commemorated the declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' as the Congress objective in 1929.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the anniversary of the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly.

options.label: D
options.text: It marked the date on which the Objectives Resolution was passed by the Assembly.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The section 'SIGNIFICANCE OF JANUARY 26' clearly states that the date was chosen because 'At the Lahore Session of the Congress held in December 1929, a resolution was passed which declared Poorna Swaraj or Complete Independence to be the objective of the Congress. January 26, 1930 was fixed as the first Independence Day'. This makes option B the correct answer.

questions.question_text: At the time of its signing, which was completed on November 26, 1949, what was the structural composition of the Constitution of India?
questions.model_answer_text: A

options.label: A
options.text: 395 Articles and 8 Schedules.

options.label: B
options.text: 299 Articles and 8 Schedules.

options.label: C
options.text: 395 Articles and 12 Schedules.

options.label: D
options.text: 389 Articles and 10 Schedules.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text, under the heading 'TIME TAKEN' and in the 'Fact File', explicitly states: 'At the time of its signing, the Constitution consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules.' This is a direct factual recall from the provided content. Other options use incorrect numbers or figures that became relevant later in the Constitution's history (like 12 Schedules).

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following key events in the making of the Indian Constitution in their correct chronological sequence:
I. The Objectives Resolution was passed by the Constituent Assembly.
II. The Drafting Committee under Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was constituted.
III. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the President of the Constituent Assembly.
IV. The members of the Constituent Assembly were elected by Provincial Legislative Assemblies.

(a) IV, III, I, II
(b) III, IV, I, II
(c) IV, I, III, II
(d) I, III, II, IV
questions.model_answer_text: (a) IV, III, I, II

answer_key.logic_explanation: The question requires the candidate to accurately sequence four distinct events spanning from 1946 to 1947. This tests detailed chronological understanding. Based on the text: IV. Elections were completed by July 1946. III. Dr. Prasad was elected on December 11, 1946. I. The Objectives Resolution was passed on January 22, 1947. II. The Drafting Committee was set up on August 29, 1947. Therefore, the correct chronological order is IV, III, I, II.

questions.question_text:
The text states that the Constituent Assembly was "truly national in character" despite its indirect election and the boycott by the Muslim League. Which of the following provides the strongest evidence from the text to support this assertion?

(a) The Assembly included members nominated by the rulers of Princely States.
(b) The Cabinet Mission Plan had provided for representation for the General category, Muslims, and Sikhs.
(c) Prominent leaders like Dr. Rajendra Prasad and Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru were part of the Assembly.
(d) Deliberate inclusion of representatives from communities like Anglo-Indians, Parsees, and Indian Christians was ensured by Congress leaders.
questions.model_answer_text: (d) Deliberate inclusion of representatives from communities like Anglo-Indians, Parsees, and Indian Christians was ensured by Congress leaders.

answer_key.logic_explanation: This question requires an analysis of the evidence presented for the Assembly's 'national character'. While options (a) and (b) are factually correct statements from the text, they do not provide the strongest support for the claim, as they describe the basic structure rather than a deliberate effort towards inclusivity. Option (d) is the strongest evidence because it highlights a conscious action taken by Congress leaders to ensure representation for communities beyond the three categories initially stipulated by the Cabinet Mission Plan, thereby making the Assembly's composition more broadly representative and 'truly national'.

questions.question_text:
Based on the principles incorporated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, what was the primary constitutional justification for establishing a single judiciary and a strong Centre?

(a) To ensure the effective implementation of the Directive Principles of State Policy.
(b) To provide special safeguards and reservations for minorities and backward classes.
(c) To maintain national integrity and uniform administrative discipline across the states.
(d) To make the Constitution flexible and workable in both peace and wartime.
questions.model_answer_text: (c) To maintain national integrity and uniform administrative discipline across the states.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The question asks for the specific reason behind a key constitutional feature championed by Dr. Ambedkar. While all options represent his broader goals, the text explicitly links the proposal for a strong Centre with the need 'to maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline'. Single judiciary and single citizenship are presented as tools to 'integrate Indian society' under this framework. Therefore, (c) is the most precise and direct justification provided in the source material.

questions.question_text:
The Objectives Resolution, proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru, laid down the foundational 'national goals'. According to the text, which of the following guarantees was NOT explicitly part of this resolution?

(a) Safeguarding the rights of minorities and backward classes.
(b) The establishment of India as a 'republic'.
(c) Granting of Fundamental Rights to all citizens.
(d) The incorporation of a Right to Constitutional Remedies.
questions.model_answer_text: (d) The incorporation of a Right to Constitutional Remedies.

answer_key.logic_explanation: This question requires careful differentiation between different stages and contributions to the Constitution. The text explicitly lists the goals of the Objectives Resolution as: (1) India as a 'republic', (2) social, political and economic democracy, (3) granting Fundamental Rights, and (4) safeguarding minorities and backward classes. Options (a), (b), and (c) are directly covered. The 'Right to Constitutional Remedies' is specifically mentioned later in the chapter as a contribution of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar to ensure Fundamental Rights are not infringed, but it is not listed as part of Nehru's initial Objectives Resolution.

questions.question_text:
Analyse the legal and institutional status of India in the interim period between the adoption of the Constitution (November 26, 1949) and its full enforcement (January 26, 1950). Which statement is most accurate according to the text?

(a) The Constituent Assembly was immediately dissolved, and Lord Mountbatten continued as Governor-General.
(b) Dr. Rajendra Prasad took over as the President of the Indian Union on November 26, 1949.
(c) The Indian Independence Act, 1947, was immediately repealed in its entirety upon the adoption of the Constitution.
(d) The Constituent Assembly functioned as a provisional parliament, and certain clauses, such as those on citizenship, came into force.
questions.model_answer_text: (d) The Constituent Assembly functioned as a provisional parliament, and certain clauses, such as those on citizenship, came into force.

answer_key.logic_explanation: This question requires a synthesis of information about the transitional phase. The text states that after signing, 'only the clauses relating to citizenship and some others came into force immediately' and 'The Constituent Assembly became the provisional parliament until the new General Elections'. This makes option (d) correct. Option (a) is incorrect because the Assembly was not dissolved and C. Rajagopalachari had replaced Mountbatten. Option (b) is incorrect as Dr. Prasad took over as President on January 26, 1950, not November 26, 1949. Option (c) is an inference not supported by the specific details in the provided text for this period.

questions.question_text:
The selection of January 26th for the commencement of the Constitution was a deliberate symbolic act rooted in the freedom struggle. How did this choice redefine the national significance of the date post-1947?

(a) It marked the anniversary of the date the Constituent Assembly was recognized as a sovereign body by the Indian Independence Act, 1947.
(b) It honoured the date on which the 'Objectives Resolution' was proposed in the Constituent Assembly.
(c) It transformed the day's identity from the pre-1947 celebration of 'Poorna Swaraj' Day to the commemoration of India becoming a Republic.
(d) It was chosen because it was the date on which the final reading and adoption of the draft Constitution was completed.
questions.model_answer_text: (c) It transformed the day's identity from the pre-1947 celebration of 'Poorna Swaraj' Day to the commemoration of India becoming a Republic.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The question assesses the understanding of the historical continuity and re-purposing of a significant date. The text explicitly states that January 26, 1930 was fixed as the 'first Independence Day' following the 'Poorna Swaraj' resolution and was celebrated as such until 1947. After independence, August 15 became Independence Day, and 'January 26 was designated as the Republic Day'. Option (c) accurately captures this transformation from its original association with 'Poorna Swaraj' to its new identity as 'Republic Day'. The other options present incorrect historical associations for this specific date.

questions.question_text:
Evaluate the following statements regarding the evolution and composition of the Constituent Assembly of India:

Statement I: The Indian Independence Act, 1947, conferred legal sovereignty upon the Constituent Assembly, which was initially constituted based on the proposals of the Cabinet Mission of 1946.
Statement II: The reduction in the Constituent Assembly's membership from 389 to 299 was a direct and immediate consequence of the Muslim League's boycott of the Assembly's first session on December 9, 1946.

Choose the correct option:
questions.model_answer_text: C. Statement I is correct, but Statement II is incorrect.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Statement I is factually correct as the text states that the Indian Independence Act, 1947, recognised the Assembly and enabled it to become a 'sovereign body'. Statement II is incorrect because while the Muslim League's boycott was a significant event, the text specifies that the reduction in membership to 299 was a result of 'members representing the territories which went to Pakistan' withdrawing from the Assembly. This withdrawal was a consequence of the Partition, not just the initial boycott. The boycott was a political protest, whereas the reduction was a structural change post-Partition.

keywords: A. Both statements are correct, and Statement II is the correct explanation of Statement I.
B. Both statements are correct, but Statement II is not the correct explanation of Statement I.
C. Statement I is correct, but Statement II is incorrect.
D. Statement I is incorrect, but Statement II is correct.

questions.question_text:
Considering the guiding principles and drafting process of the Indian Constitution, analyse the alignment between the foundational objectives and the specific constitutional provisions mentioned in the text.

1.  **Foundational Objective:** The state would safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes. **Constitutional Provision:** Laid down as a 'national goal' in the Objectives Resolution proposed on December 13, 1946.
2.  **Foundational Objective:** To ensure the liberty and dignity of the individual. **Constitutional Provision:** Incorporated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar through the Right to Constitutional Remedies, ensuring Fundamental Rights are not infringed.
3.  **Foundational Objective:** To ensure social and economic democracy. **Constitutional Provision:** Incorporated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar through the Directive Principles.

Which of the above pairings of 'Foundational Objective' and 'Constitutional Provision' are correctly matched as per the provided chapter content?
questions.model_answer_text: D. 1, 2 and 3

answer_key.logic_explanation: All three pairings are correctly matched based on the text. 1) The text on the 'Objectives Resolution' explicitly states it aimed to 'safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes'. 2) The section on 'Dr. Ambedkar's Contribution' mentions his role was to ensure 'liberty and dignity of the individual' and that he 'Incorporated the Right to Constitutional Remedies to ensure that the Fundamental Rights of the individuals are not infringed'. 3) The same section explicitly states he 'Incorporated Directive Principles to ensure social and economic democracy'. The question requires synthesizing information from multiple sub-sections to validate all three statements.

questions.question_text:
Given below in Column A are some key events related to the making of the Indian Constitution, and in Column B are the corresponding dates. Match them correctly and choose the correct option from the choices given below.

| Column A (Event)                                | Column B (Date)          |
|-------------------------------------------------|--------------------------|
| 1. First sitting of the Constituent Assembly    | a. January 26, 1950      |
| 2. Adoption of the Constitution                 | b. December 13, 1946     |
| 3. Enforcement of the Constitution              | c. December 9, 1946      |
| 4. Proposal of the 'Objectives Resolution'     | d. November 26, 1949     |

Options:
A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b
B. 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d
C. 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b
D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a
questions.model_answer_text: A

answer_key.logic_explanation:
The correct matches based on the chapter content are:
- The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held on December 9, 1946. (1-c)
- The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949. (2-d)
- The Constitution as a whole came into force with effect from January 26, 1950. (3-a)
- Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' on December 13, 1946. (4-b)
Therefore, the correct combination is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b, which corresponds to option A.

questions.question_text:
Given below in Column A are the names of prominent figures associated with the Constituent Assembly, and in Column B are their roles or associations. Match them correctly and choose the correct option from the choices given below.

| Column A (Person)             | Column B (Role / Association)                               |
|-------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1. Dr. Rajendra Prasad        | a. Chairman of the Drafting Committee                       |
| 2. Dr. Sachidananda Sinha     | b. Proposed the 'Objectives Resolution'                     |
| 3. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar          | c. President of the Constituent Assembly                    |
| 4. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru       | d. Presided over the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly |

Options:
A. 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d
B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b
C. 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c
D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a
questions.model_answer_text: B

answer_key.logic_explanation:
The correct matches based on the chapter content are:
- On December 11, 1946, Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected President of the Constituent Assembly. (1-c)
- The first sitting was presided over by Dr. Sachidananda Sinha. (2-d)
- The Drafting Committee, under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was set up on August 29, 1947. (3-a)
- Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' on December 13, 1946. (4-b)
Therefore, the correct combination is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b, which corresponds to option B.

questions.question_text:
Directions: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

**Assertion (A):** The Constituent Assembly of India became a sovereign body after the Indian Independence Act, 1947.
**Reason (R):** The Cabinet Mission Plan of 1946, which proposed the Constituent Assembly, had granted it sovereign status to draft the constitution for an independent India.

(a) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true, but R is false.
(d) A is false, but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is correct as the Indian Independence Act, 1947, gave legal sanction and sovereignty to the Assembly, allowing it to function independently of British control. Reason (R) is incorrect because the Cabinet Mission Plan operated under the framework of British authority; sovereignty was not granted by the Plan but was a consequence of the transfer of power through the Independence Act.

keywords: (c) A is true, but R is false.

questions.question_text:
Given below are two columns. Column I lists various communities and Column II lists their representatives in the Constituent Assembly. Match them correctly and choose the right option.

| Column I (Community)      | Column II (Representative) |
|---------------------------|----------------------------|
| 1. Anglo-Indians          | a. Dr. H.P. Modi           |
| 2. Parsees                | b. Sardar Hukum Singh      |
| 3. Sikhs                  | c. Dr. H.C. Mukherjee      |
| 4. Indian Christians      | d. Mr. Frank Anthony       |

(a) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c
(b) 1-a, 2-d, 3-c, 4-b
(c) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b
(d) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

Directions: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

**Assertion (A):** The 'Objectives Resolution' laid down the 'national goals' and philosophical foundation for the Constitution of India.
**Reason (R):** The resolution declared that Free India would be a republic, guaranteeing Fundamental Rights and ideals of social, political, and economic democracy.

(a) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true, but R is false.
(d) A is false, but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is correct as the Objectives Resolution, proposed by Pt. Nehru, defined the guiding principles and philosophy for the constitution-makers. Reason (R) is also correct as it lists the specific goals contained within the resolution. R provides the correct explanation for A because these specific declarations (republic, Fundamental Rights, democracy) are the very 'national goals' and philosophical foundations mentioned in A.

keywords: (a) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

questions.question_text:
Directions: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

**Assertion (A):** The Constitution of India was adopted and came into full force on November 26, 1949.
**Reason (R):** The date January 26 was chosen for the formal commencement of the Constitution to commemorate the 'Poorna Swaraj' declaration made at the Lahore Session of Congress in 1929.

(a) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true, but R is false.
(d) A is false, but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is false because while the Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949, it came into full force on January 26, 1950. Only certain provisions, such as those related to citizenship, came into effect immediately on the date of adoption. Reason (R) is true as the text explicitly states that January 26 was chosen for its historical significance, linking it to the declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' and its first celebration as 'Independence Day' in 1930.

keywords: (d) A is false, but R is true.

questions.question_text:
Study the table below which matches individuals to their roles or the communities they represented in the Constituent Assembly. Identify the correctly matched pairs.

| Column I (Community/Role)       | Column II (Representative/Chairman) |
|---------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| (A) Anglo-Indians               | (i) Dr. H.C. Mukherjee              |
| (B) Drafting Committee Chairman | (ii) Dr. B.R. Ambedkar              |
| (C) Parsees                     | (iii) Dr. H.P. Modi                 |
| (D) President of Constituent Assembly | (iv) Dr. Sachidananda Sinha       |

Select the option that correctly identifies the matched pairs.

(a) Only (A) and (D) are correct.
(b) Only (B) and (C) are correct.
(c) Only (A), (B), and (C) are correct.
(d) Only (B) is correct.
questions.model_answer_text: (b) Only (B) and (C) are correct.

answer_key.logic_explanation:
The evaluation of each pair is as follows:
- (A) is incorrect. The text states that Anglo-Indians were represented by Mr. Frank Anthony and Mr. S.H. Prater. Dr. H.C. Mukherjee represented Indian Christians.
- (B) is correct. The text explicitly mentions that the Drafting Committee was under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
- (C) is correct. The text states that the Parsees were represented by Dr. H.P. Modi.
- (D) is incorrect. Dr. Sachidananda Sinha presided over the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly as its oldest member. However, Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the President on December 11, 1946. Therefore, Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the President of the Constituent Assembly. 
Thus, only pairs (B) and (C) are correctly matched.

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements, marked as Statement I (Assertion) and Statement II (Reason). Read the statements and choose the correct option from the choices given below.

**Statement I (Assertion):** The Constitution of India incorporated principles such as single citizenship, a single judiciary, and a strong Centre to ensure national integrity and administrative discipline.

**Statement II (Reason):** The 'Objectives Resolution', passed on January 22, 1947, explicitly laid down these structural principles of single citizenship and a strong Centre as national goals.

(a) Both Statement I and Statement II are true, and Statement II is the correct explanation of Statement I.
(b) Both Statement I and Statement II are true, but Statement II is not the correct explanation of Statement I.
(c) Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.
(d) Statement I is false, but Statement II is true.
questions.model_answer_text: (c) Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.

keywords: (c) Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Statement I is true. The text, under 'Dr. Ambedkar's Contribution to the Indian Constitution', states that he incorporated principles like 'single citizenship, single judiciary' and proposed a 'strong Centre to maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline'. Statement II is false. The text lists the goals of the 'Objectives Resolution' as: India being a 'republic', guaranteeing 'social, political and economic democracy', granting 'Fundamental Rights', and safeguarding the rights of 'minorities and backward classes'. It does not mention structural principles like single citizenship or a strong Centre. These contributions are credited to Dr. Ambedkar's work in the Drafting Committee, not Nehru's Objectives Resolution. Therefore, Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.

questions.question_text:
Direction: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

**Assertion (A):** The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held on December 9, 1946.
**Reason (R):** The Cabinet Mission of 1946 proposed the establishment of a Constituent Assembly whose members were to be elected by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies.

(A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
(B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(C) A is true, but R is false.
(D) A is false, but R is true.
questions.model_answer_text: A

answer_key.logic_explanation: The Assertion is factually correct as the first session of the Constituent Assembly began on December 9, 1946. The Reason is also factually correct as the Cabinet Mission's proposal was the basis for the formation of the Constituent Assembly. The Reason correctly explains the Assertion because the Assembly was formed and held its first meeting as a direct consequence of the Cabinet Mission's plan.

questions.question_text:
Direction: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

**Assertion (A):** The Constitution of India was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949.
**Reason (R):** January 26 was chosen as the date for the full enforcement of the Constitution to commemorate the 'Poorna Swaraj' resolution of the Lahore Session of 1929.

(A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
(B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(C) A is true, but R is false.
(D) A is false, but R is true.
questions.model_answer_text: B

answer_key.logic_explanation: The Assertion is factually correct; the Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949. The Reason is also factually correct; January 26 was chosen as the date of commencement due to its historical significance related to the 'Poorna Swaraj' day (January 26, 1930). However, the Reason explains the choice of the date of *enforcement* (January 26, 1950), not the date of *adoption* (November 26, 1949), which was the day the drafting process concluded. Therefore, both statements are individually true, but R is not the correct explanation for A.

questions.question_text:
Direction: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

Assertion (A): The Constitution of India is a fundamental legal document that restrains the government from taking arbitrary decisions.
Reason (R): It regulates the position and powers of the legislative, executive, and judiciary, and moderates relations between the government and the governed.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is correct as the text states the Constitution 'protects the interests of the citizens by restraining the government from taking arbitrary decisions.' Reason (R) is also correct as the text states it 'regulates the position and powers of the three organs of the government' and 'moderates relations between the government and the governed.' Reason (R) correctly explains Assertion (A) because the method by which the Constitution restrains arbitrary power is by clearly defining the powers and roles of government organs and establishing the relationship between the state and its citizens.

questions.question_text:
Direction: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

Assertion (A): The total membership of the Constituent Assembly of India was reduced from 389 to 299.
Reason (R): The Indian Independence Act, 1947, formalised the creation of two independent states, leading to the withdrawal of members representing territories that formed Pakistan.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is a factual statement directly from the text. Reason (R) is also factually correct; the Indian Independence Act, 1947, created India and Pakistan. The text states that 'the members representing the territories which went to Pakistan withdrew from the Constituent Assembly of India. As a result, the membership...stood at 299'. Therefore, the event described in Reason (R) is the direct cause of the outcome mentioned in Assertion (A).

questions.question_text:
Direction: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

Assertion (A): The Constituent Assembly, despite its formation under the Cabinet Mission plan, was considered to be truly national in character.
Reason (R): The Objectives Resolution, passed on January 22, 1947, laid down national goals such as guaranteeing Fundamental Rights and safeguarding the rights of minorities.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is true; the text explicitly states, 'It can be said that the Constituent Assembly was truly national in character.' Reason (R) is also true, as the text confirms that the Objectives Resolution aimed to grant Fundamental Rights and safeguard minorities. However, Reason (R) is not the correct explanation for Assertion (A). The text explains the 'national character' of the Assembly by referencing its diverse *composition* (representation for Anglo-Indians, Christians, Parsees, etc.), not its stated *objectives*. The composition made it representative, while the resolution outlined its future goals.

questions.question_text:
Direction: In the following question, a statement of Assertion (A) is followed by a statement of Reason (R). Mark the correct choice.

Assertion (A): The entire Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.
Reason (R): The date January 26 was chosen to commemorate the 'Poorna Swaraj' resolution passed at the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is false. The text clearly states, 'After the signing of the Constitution, only the clauses relating to citizenship and some others came into force immediately.' This occurred on November 26, 1949, the date of adoption. The Constitution 'as a whole' came into force on January 26, 1950, but not the 'entire' Constitution on that single day. Reason (R) is true. The text explicitly links the choice of January 26 to the historical importance of the 'Poorna Swaraj' resolution and the celebration of the first 'Independence Day' on January 26, 1930.

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements, an Assertion (A) and a Reason (R). Read the statements and choose the correct option.

**Assertion (A):** The Constituent Assembly, as conceptualised by the Cabinet Mission Plan, was an indirectly elected body whose initial strength for undivided India was set at 389 members.

**Reason (R):** The Cabinet Mission Plan was designed to be inclusory, ensuring direct representation for a wide array of communities such as Anglo-Indians, Indian Christians, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes, thereby establishing a truly national character for the Assembly from its outset.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.
questions.model_answer_text: (c) A is true but R is false.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is factually correct. The text states that the members of the Constituent Assembly were 'elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies' and that the 'Constituent Assembly of undivided India consisted of 389 members'. Reason (R) is factually incorrect. The text specifies that the Cabinet Mission plan itself 'had ensured representation to only three categoriesâ€”the General category, Muslims and Sikhs'. It was the effort of 'The Congress leaders' that ensured other communities like Anglo-Indians, Indian Christians, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes received representation. Therefore, the plan itself was not as broadly inclusory as stated in the Reason. Since A is true and R is false, the correct option is (c).

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements, an Assertion (A) and a Reason (R). Read the statements and choose the correct option.

**Assertion (A):** While the Constitution of India was passed and adopted on November 26, 1949, with some provisions like citizenship coming into immediate effect, its full commencement was deferred to January 26, 1950.

**Reason (R):** The date of January 26 was chosen for the full enforcement of the Constitution to commemorate the passing of the 'Objectives Resolution', proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru, which laid down the national goals and guiding principles for the constitution-making process.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.
questions.model_answer_text: (c) A is true but R is false.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Assertion (A) is factually correct. The text explicitly states that the Constitution was 'adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949,' and that 'only the clauses relating to citizenship and some others came into force immediately.' It further confirms that 'The Constitution as a whole came into force with effect from January 26, 1950.' Reason (R) is factually incorrect. The text clarifies that the 'Objectives Resolution' was passed on 'January 22, 1947'. The significance of January 26 is tied to the Lahore Session of Congress in December 1929, which declared 'Poorna Swaraj', and designated 'January 26, 1930' as the first Independence Day. Therefore, the Reason provides an incorrect historical justification for the chosen date. Since A is true and R is false, the correct option is (c).

questions.question_text:
Identify the odd one out from the following list of figures associated with the Constituent Assembly, based on the roles mentioned in the text.

(a) Mr. Frank Anthony
(b) Dr. H.P. Modi
(c) Dr. Sachidananda Sinha
(d) Sardar Hukum Singh
questions.model_answer_text: (c) Dr. Sachidananda Sinha

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text identifies Mr. Frank Anthony, Dr. H.P. Modi, and Sardar Hukum Singh as representatives of the Anglo-Indian, Parsee, and Sikh communities respectively. Dr. Sachidananda Sinha is mentioned as the oldest member who presided over the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly, which is a functional role, making him the odd one out in a group of community representatives.

questions.question_text:
Identify the odd one out from the following list of personalities based on their specific role within the Constituent Assembly's framework.
(a) Dr. Rajendra Prasad
(b) Dr. Sachidananda Sinha
(c) Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
(d) C. Rajagopalachari
questions.model_answer_text: (d) C. Rajagopalachari

answer_key.logic_explanation: Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the President of the Constituent Assembly, Dr. Sachidananda Sinha was the temporary President of its first sitting, and Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee. All three held key presiding or committee leadership roles within the Constituent Assembly. C. Rajagopalachari, however, became the Governor-General, an executive position of the state after Lord Mountbatten, and was not a presiding officer within the Assembly itself.

questions.question_text:
The 'Objectives Resolution' proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946, outlined the guiding principles for the Constitution. Which of the following principles was NOT explicitly stated in this Resolution as per the provided text?
(a) The guarantee of social, political and economic democracy.
(b) The establishment of a single citizenship and a single judiciary.
(c) The safeguarding of rights for minorities and backward classes.
(d) The provision of Fundamental Rights for all citizens.
questions.model_answer_text: (b) The establishment of a single citizenship and a single judiciary.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The text lists four key points from the Objectives Resolution: India as a 'republic', ensuring 'social, political and economic democracy', granting 'Fundamental Rights', and safeguarding the rights of 'minorities and backward classes'. The concepts of single citizenship and a single judiciary, while later incorporated into the Constitution and attributed to Dr. Ambedkar's vision for a strong Centre, were not part of the initial 'national goals' outlined in the Objectives Resolution.

questions.question_text:
The Constituent Assembly was considered 'truly national in character' due to its wide-ranging representation. Based on the specific examples provided in the text, identify the community that is the odd one out.
(a) Anglo-Indians
(b) Parsees
(c) Jains
(d) Indian Christians
questions.model_answer_text: (c) Jains

answer_key.logic_explanation: The chapter content explicitly mentions that representation was ensured for various communities and provides specific examples. It states that the Anglo-Indians were represented by Mr. Frank Anthony, the Indian Christians by Dr. H.C. Mukherjee, and the Parsees by Dr. H.P. Modi. The Jain community is not mentioned in this specific list of examples, making it the odd one out in the context of the provided text.

questions.question_text: Identify the odd one out from the following principles incorporated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar into the Constitution, based on their primary constitutional objective.
questions.model_answer_text: B

criteria.label: Provision for single citizenship and uniformity in fundamental laws.
keywords: Provision for single citizenship and uniformity in fundamental laws.

criteria.label: Incorporation of the Right to Constitutional Remedies.
keywords: Incorporation of the Right to Constitutional Remedies.

criteria.label: Proposal for a strong Centre to maintain territorial integrity.
keywords: Proposal for a strong Centre to maintain territorial integrity.

criteria.label: Incorporation of Directive Principles of State Policy.
keywords: Incorporation of Directive Principles of State Policy.

answer_key.logic_explanation: Options (A), (C), and (D) are principles aimed at establishing the nature and structure of the state and its socio-economic goals. (A) and (C) focus on national unity and administrative integrity ('strong Centre', 'single citizenship'). (D) focuses on establishing 'social and economic democracy'. Option (B), the Right to Constitutional Remedies, is distinct as it is a specific justiciable mechanism designed to enforce and protect the Fundamental Rights of individual citizens against state infringement, making it the odd one out in terms of its primary objective being the direct empowerment and protection of the individual's civil liberties.

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following events related to the formation of the Indian Constitution in the correct chronological sequence:
I. The Drafting Committee was set up under the chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
II. The 'Objectives Resolution' was passed by the Constituent Assembly.
III. The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly.
IV. The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held.

(A) IV, II, I, III
(B) I, II, IV, III
(C) IV, I, II, III
(D) II, IV, I, III
questions.model_answer_text:
(A) IV, II, I, III. 
The correct chronological order is:
- The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly (IV) was held on December 9, 1946.
- The 'Objectives Resolution' (II) was passed on January 22, 1947.
- The Drafting Committee (I) was set up on August 29, 1947.
- The Constitution was adopted and passed (III) on November 26, 1949.

blocks.label: Select the correct sequence of events.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The question requires arranging key events in the making of the Indian Constitution chronologically. Based on the provided text, the dates are: First sitting of the Constituent Assembly (December 9, 1946), Passing of the 'Objectives Resolution' (January 22, 1947), Setting up of the Drafting Committee (August 29, 1947), and Adoption of the Constitution (November 26, 1949). Therefore, the correct sequence of the numbered events is IV, II, I, III.

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following events related to the formation and initial proceedings of the Constituent Assembly in their correct chronological sequence.
(i) Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the President of the Constituent Assembly.
(ii) The Cabinet Mission arrived in India.
(iii) Elections to the Provincial Legislative Assemblies were completed.
(iv) The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held, presided over by Dr. Sachidananda Sinha.

(A) (ii), (iv), (iii), (i)
(B) (iii), (ii), (iv), (i)
(C) (ii), (iii), (iv), (i)
(D) (iv), (i), (ii), (iii)
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation: The correct chronological order is: (ii) The Cabinet Mission arrived in India (1946), which proposed the Constituent Assembly. (iii) Elections to the Provincial Legislative Assemblies were completed (by July 1946). (iv) The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held (December 9, 1946). (i) Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as its President (December 11, 1946).

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following key milestones in the framing of the Indian Constitution in the correct chronological order.
(i) The Constituent Assembly passed the 'Objectives Resolution'.
(ii) The Drafting Committee was set up under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
(iii) Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution'.
(iv) The Constituent Assembly became a sovereign body, a status recognised by the Indian Independence Act, 1947.

(A) (iii), (i), (iv), (ii)
(B) (i), (iii), (ii), (iv)
(C) (iii), (iv), (i), (ii)
(D) (iv), (iii), (i), (ii)
questions.model_answer_text: A

answer_key.logic_explanation: The correct chronological order is: (iii) Pt. Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' (December 13, 1946). (i) The 'Objectives Resolution' was passed (January 22, 1947). (iv) The Assembly became a sovereign body after the Indian Independence Act, 1947 (effective August 1947). (ii) The Drafting Committee was subsequently set up (August 29, 1947).

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following events concerning the finalisation and implementation of the Constitution in their correct chronological sequence.
(i) The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly.
(ii) Dr. Rajendra Prasad took over as the President of the Indian Union.
(iii) The second Reading of the Draft Constitution was completed.
(iv) The provisions relating to citizenship came into immediate force.

(A) (iii), (iv), (i), (ii)
(B) (iii), (i), (iv), (ii)
(C) (i), (iii), (iv), (ii)
(D) (ii), (iii), (i), (iv)
questions.model_answer_text: B

answer_key.logic_explanation: The correct chronological order is: (iii) The second Reading was completed (October 17, 1949). (i) The Constitution was adopted and passed after the third reading (November 26, 1949). (iv) Provisions on citizenship came into force immediately after adoption (November 26, 1949). (ii) Dr. Rajendra Prasad became President when the Constitution fully came into force and India became a Republic (January 26, 1950).

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following milestones in the framing of the Indian Constitution in their correct chronological order:

1.  The 'Objectives Resolution', having laid down the 'national goals', was passed by the Constituent Assembly.
2.  The Constituent Assembly, now a sovereign body following the Indian Independence Act, 1947, set up the Drafting Committee under Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's chairmanship.
3.  The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held, presided over by Dr. Sachidananda Sinha.
4.  The Second Reading of the draft Constitution, following clause-by-clause discussions, was completed.
questions.model_answer_text: C

answer_key.logic_explanation:
The correct chronological sequence of events is as follows: 
1. **(3) First sitting of the Constituent Assembly:** This occurred on December 9, 1946. 
2. **(1) 'Objectives Resolution' passed:** Proposed on Dec 13, 1946, it was passed on January 22, 1947. 
3. **(2) Drafting Committee set up:** This was established on August 29, 1947, after the Indian Independence Act, 1947. 
4. **(4) Second Reading completed:** This procedural step in finalising the draft was completed much later, on October 17, 1949. 
Therefore, the correct sequence is 3, 1, 2, 4.

questions.question_text:
Read the following excerpt and answer the question that follows:

"At the Lahore Session of the Congress held in December 1929, a resolution was passed which declared Poorna Swaraj or Complete Independence to be the objective of the Congress. January 26, 1930 was fixed as the first Independence Day, which was to be so celebrated every year. Since then the day was celebrated as Independence Day up to 1947."

Based on the information in the excerpt and your knowledge of the chapter, why was the date of January 26th specifically chosen for the enforcement of the Constitution of India?

A. It was the day the Cabinet Mission published its proposals.
B. It was the date of the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly.
C. It held historical importance as the day first celebrated for 'Poorna Swaraj'.
D. It was the day Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected President of the Constituent Assembly.
questions.model_answer_text: C. It held historical importance as the day first celebrated for 'Poorna Swaraj'.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The source text explicitly links the date January 26th to the declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) at the Lahore Session of 1929. The chapter content confirms this historical significance was the reason for selecting this date to enforce the Constitution, thereby making it Republic Day.

keywords: It held historical importance as the day first celebrated for 'Poorna Swaraj'.

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements, Assertion (A) and Reason (R). Read the statements and choose the correct option.

**Assertion (A):** The membership of the Constituent Assembly of India was reduced from the original 389 members to 299.
**Reason (R):** The Muslim League boycotted the Constituent Assembly to demand the creation of a separate state, leading to the withdrawal of members representing territories that became part of Pakistan.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.
questions.model_answer_text: (a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The Assertion (A) correctly states the reduction in the Constituent Assembly's membership from 389 to 299. The Reason (R) accurately explains why this happened: the Muslim League's boycott and the subsequent partition of India meant that members representing the territories of Pakistan withdrew from the Assembly. Therefore, R is the direct and correct explanation for A.

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements, Assertion (A) and Reason (R). Read the statements and choose the correct option.

**Assertion (A):** The Constitution of India, though adopted on November 26, 1949, was brought into force on January 26, 1950.
**Reason (R):** The date January 26 was specifically chosen to commemorate the 'Poorna Swaraj' resolution passed at the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929.

(a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
(b) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
(c) A is true but R is false.
(d) A is false but R is true.
questions.model_answer_text: (a) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.

answer_key.logic_explanation: The Assertion (A) accurately states the dates of adoption and enforcement of the Constitution. The Reason (R) provides the correct historical significance behind choosing January 26 as the date of enforcement. The text explicitly links the commencement date to the declaration of 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) at the Lahore Session and the celebration of the first 'Independence Day' on January 26, 1930. Thus, R is the correct explanation for A.

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements, an Assertion (A) and a Reason (R), related to the finalisation of the Indian Constitution. Read the statements and choose the correct option.

**Assertion (A):** On November 26, 1949, when the Constitution was finally passed and adopted, it was signed by 284 members of the Constituent Assembly.

**Reason (R):** The original strength of the Constituent Assembly of undivided India, which stood at 389, was significantly reduced due to the boycott by the Muslim League and the subsequent withdrawal of members from territories that formed Pakistan.
questions.model_answer_text: (a) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

keywords: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

answer_key.logic_explanation:
1. **Assertion (A) Analysis:** The statement that 284 members signed the Constitution on November 26, 1949, is factually correct as per the provided text: "...284 were actually present on November 26, 1949, and appended their signatures to the Constitution as finally passed." Therefore, Assertion (A) is true.
2. **Reason (R) Analysis:** The statement that the Assembly's strength was reduced from 389 due to the Muslim League boycott and partition is also factually correct. The text confirms the original number was 389 and explains: "The Muslim League boycotted the Constituent Assembly... Consequently, the members representing the territories which went to Pakistan withdrew... As a result, the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India stood at 299 against the original number of 389 members." Therefore, Reason (R) is true.
3. **Connection Analysis:** The Reason (R) explains the historical event that led to the reduction of the Assembly's total membership to 299. The Assertion (A) states the number of members (284) who were present to sign out of this reduced total of 299. The reduction mentioned in R is the direct cause for why the pool of potential signatories was 299 and not the original 389. Thus, R provides the necessary context and is the correct explanation for the situation described in A. The question requires connecting information from two separate paragraphs about the Assembly's composition and the final signing.

questions.question_text:

Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee. Similarly, the provided text states that Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the Objectives Resolution, which laid down the national goals and guiding principles for the Constitution.

(D) C. Rajagopalachari
questions.model_answer_text: C

Dr. Sachidananda Sinha, being the oldest member, presided over the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly on December 9, 1946. Subsequently, on December 11, 1946, Dr. Rajendra Prasad was formally elected as the President of the Constituent Assembly.

questions.question_text:

Lahore Session Resolution (1929) : Poorna Swaraj :: Objectives Resolution (1946) : ________.
(A) Division of India
(B) National Goals
(C) Single Citizenship
(D) Abolition of Untouchability
questions.model_answer_text: B

answer_key.logic_explanation: The analogy establishes a relationship between a foundational political document and its primary aim or objective. The resolution of the Lahore Session of Congress in 1929 declared 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) as its objective. Similarly, the 'Objectives Resolution' proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru in 1946 laid down the 'national goals' for the future Indian republic, such as social, political, and economic democracy, and the guarantee of Fundamental Rights.

questions.question_text:
Identify the pair that shares a relationship analogous to the one between the Lahore Session (1929) and the date January 26, 1950, where a pre-existing historical event provides the symbolic basis for a new constitutional date.

(a) Cabinet Mission : Constituent Assembly
(b) Dr. Sachidananda Sinha : Dr. Rajendra Prasad
(c) Constituent Assembly : Provisional Parliament
(d) Objectives Resolution : Fundamental Rights
questions.model_answer_text: (c) Constituent Assembly : Provisional Parliament

answer_key.logic_explanation: The primary relationship is one of continuity, where a pre-republican event or entity is carried forward into the new constitutional era. The Lahore Session's resolution on 'Poorna Swaraj' gave January 26th its historical significance, making it the symbolic choice for Republic Day. Analogously, the Constituent Assembly, a pre-republican body, transformed its function to become the Provisional Parliament after the Constitution's commencement, thus continuing as a key institution. Option (a) represents a proposal and its outcome. Option (b) represents a succession from a temporary head to an elected one. Option (d) represents a guiding principle and its resulting constitutional provision.

questions.question_text: What is a Constitution and what is its main aim?
questions.model_answer_text: A Constitution is a comprehensive document containing the set of rules describing the rights and duties of its citizens and the manner of governance. Its main aim is to ensure smooth governance for the welfare of its citizens.

questions.question_text: Who was the first person to preside over the Constituent Assembly's sittings? On which date was the first sitting held?
questions.model_answer_text: Dr. Sachidananda Sinha, the oldest sitting member, presided over the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly. The first sitting was held on December 9, 1946.

questions.question_text: How were the members from the Princely States represented in the Constituent Assembly?
questions.model_answer_text: The Princely States were represented by members nominated by the rulers of these States.

questions.question_text: Who proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' and on what date?
questions.model_answer_text: Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' on December 13, 1946.

questions.question_text: Who was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee of the Constituent Assembly?

questions.question_text: State any two communities, other than the general category, Muslims and Sikhs, that were given representation in the Constituent Assembly.

questions.question_text: Mention one principle incorporated by Dr. Ambedkar to ensure social and economic democracy.
questions.model_answer_text: Dr. Ambedkar incorporated the Directive Principles to ensure social and economic democracy and the welfare of the people of India.

questions.question_text: Approximately how much time did the Constituent Assembly take to pass the Constitution?

questions.question_text: On which date was the Constitution of India adopted and passed? When did it come into force?
questions.model_answer_text: The Constitution was adopted and passed on November 26, 1949. It came into force on January 26, 1950.

questions.question_text: What was the historical significance of January 26 that led to it being chosen as India's Republic Day?
questions.model_answer_text: At the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929, a resolution for 'Poorna Swaraj' was passed, and January 26, 1930 was fixed and celebrated as the first Independence Day.
