questions.question_text: When was the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly held? Who was elected as its President on December 11, 1946?
questions.model_answer_text: The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held on December 9, 1946. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as its President on December 11, 1946.

questions.question_text: Who proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' in the Constituent Assembly? State any two objectives laid down in this resolution.
questions.model_answer_text:
Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru proposed the 'Objectives Resolution'.
Any two of the following objectives:
1. Free India will be a 'republic'.
2. The ideals of social, political and economic democracy would be guaranteed to all people.
3. The republic would grant Fundamental Rights to citizens.
4. The state would safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes.

questions.question_text: Explain two ways in which the Constitution of India regulates the governance of the country.
questions.model_answer_text:
The Constitution of India regulates governance in two key ways: 
1. It defines the position and powers of the three organs of the governmentâ€”the legislative, executive, and judiciary, and states how they are inter-related.
2. It moderates the relationship between the government and the governed by protecting the interests of citizens and restraining the government from taking arbitrary decisions.

questions.question_text: Describe the method by which members were to be chosen for the Constituent Assembly as proposed by the Cabinet Mission in 1946.
questions.model_answer_text:
The Cabinet Mission proposed a dual method for choosing members:
1. Members from the provinces were to be elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies (Lower House only).
2. Members from the Princely States were to be represented by members nominated by the rulers of these States.

questions.question_text: State the impact of the Muslim League's boycott on the composition of the Constituent Assembly.
questions.model_answer_text: The Muslim League boycotted the Constituent Assembly to demand Pakistan. Consequently, when India was partitioned, the members representing the territories that went to Pakistan withdrew. This resulted in the reduction of the Assembly's membership from the original 389 to 299 members.

questions.question_text: The Constituent Assembly was described as 'truly national in character'. Name the representatives for the Anglo-Indian and the Parsee communities to support this.
questions.model_answer_text: The representative for the Anglo-Indian community was Mr. Frank Anthony (or Mr. S.H. Prater). The representative for the Parsee community was Dr. H.P. Modi.

questions.question_text: State any two key 'national goals' laid down in the 'Objectives Resolution' proposed by Jawaharlal Nehru.
questions.model_answer_text:
Two key national goals laid down in the 'Objectives Resolution' were:
1. To declare that Free India would be a 'republic'.
2. To guarantee Fundamental Rights to all citizens and to safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes.

questions.question_text: Mention two constitutional guarantees for civil liberties that were incorporated into the Constitution by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar.
questions.model_answer_text:
The text of the Constitution prepared by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar provided for several constitutional guarantees for civil liberties, including:
1. Freedom of religion for all individual citizens.
2. The abolition of untouchability.

questions.question_text: Explain Dr. B.R. Ambedkarâ€™s rationale for proposing a strong Centre with provisions like single citizenship and a single judiciary.
questions.model_answer_text: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar proposed features like a strong Centre, single citizenship, and a single judiciary in order to integrate Indian society. He believed these provisions were necessary to maintain the territorial integrity and administrative discipline of the nation.

questions.question_text: State the date when the Constitution of India was adopted and passed. How many Articles and Schedules did it contain at that time?
questions.model_answer_text: The Constitution of India was adopted and passed on November 26, 1949. At the time of its signing, it consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules.

questions.question_text: Why was the date January 26 specifically chosen for the enforcement and commencement of the Constitution of India?
questions.model_answer_text: The date January 26 was chosen for its historical importance. It commemorates the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929, which passed the 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) resolution. Following this resolution, January 26, 1930, was celebrated as the first Independence Day.

questions.question_text: What role did the Constituent Assembly assume after the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950, and for how long?
questions.model_answer_text: After the Constitution came into force, the Constituent Assembly became the provisional Parliament of India. It continued to function in this capacity until the first General Elections were held in 1951â€“52.

questions.question_text: What was the 'Objectives Resolution'? State any two of its primary objectives.
questions.model_answer_text:
The 'Objectives Resolution' was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946, to highlight the objectives and lay down the national goals for the new Constitution.
Two of its primary objectives were:
1. To declare that free India would be a 'republic'.
2. To guarantee Fundamental Rights to all its citizens.
(Other valid points: to ensure social, political and economic democracy; to safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes).

questions.question_text: How did the composition of the Constituent Assembly change after the Muslim League's boycott? Name one representative each for the Anglo-Indian and Parsee communities in the Assembly.
questions.model_answer_text:
Following the boycott by the Muslim League to demand Pakistan, the members representing the territories which went to Pakistan withdrew from the Constituent Assembly. Consequently, the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India was reduced from the original 389 members to 299.
Representative for Anglo-Indians: Mr. Frank Anthony (or Mr. S.H. Prater).
Representative for Parsees: Dr. H.P. Modi.

questions.question_text: Mention any two key contributions of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar in drafting the Constitution that aimed to ensure social justice and protect individual liberties.
questions.model_answer_text:
Two key contributions of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar were:
1. He provided for constitutional guarantees and special safeguards for minorities and certain classes who are socially and educationally backward, such as the system of reservation of jobs.
2. He incorporated the Right to Constitutional Remedies to ensure that the Fundamental Rights of individuals are not infringed by the Centre or the State governments.

questions.question_text: Explain the historical significance of the date January 26, which led to its selection for the enforcement of the Indian Constitution.
questions.model_answer_text: The date January 26 was chosen because of its historical importance. At the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929, a resolution was passed declaring 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) as the objective. Following this, January 26, 1930, was celebrated as the first 'Independence Day'. To commemorate this historic event, January 26 was designated as Republic Day, the day the Constitution came into force.

questions.question_text: State the difference between the adoption and the enforcement of the Constitution of India, mentioning the specific dates for each.
questions.model_answer_text:
The adoption of the Constitution refers to the date on which it was passed and signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly, which was November 26, 1949.
The enforcement of the Constitution refers to the date on which it fully came into effect, and India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic. This date was January 26, 1950.

questions.question_text: Following the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly on December 9, 1946, its membership underwent a significant reduction. State the primary reason for this change and specify the original and revised strength of the Assembly. Furthermore, mention the exact number of members who appended their signatures to the finally passed Constitution.
questions.model_answer_text: The primary reason for the reduction in the Constituent Assembly's membership was the boycott by the Muslim League, which demanded a separate state of Pakistan. Consequently, members representing territories that became part of Pakistan withdrew. The original strength of the Assembly for undivided India was 389 members. After the withdrawal of Muslim League members, the revised strength for the Constituent Assembly of India stood at 299 members. Finally, 284 members were actually present and appended their signatures to the Constitution on November 26, 1949.

questions.question_text: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is credited with proposing a strong Centre to maintain territorial integrity. Justify this statement by explaining two constitutional mechanisms he incorporated to promote national unity, as mentioned in the provided text.
questions.model_answer_text:
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar advocated for a strong Centre to maintain national integrity and administrative discipline. He incorporated two key constitutional mechanisms to achieve this:
1. Single Citizenship: This ensures that every citizen of India has the same rights and privileges, irrespective of the state they reside in, fostering a common Indian identity and preventing regional allegiances from overriding national ones.
2. Single Judiciary: He established an integrated judicial system to ensure uniformity in the application of fundamental laws across the country. This prevents legal fragmentation and reinforces the authority of the Union's legal framework.

questions.question_text: The Indian Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949, but its full enforcement was deferred to January 26, 1950. Explain the historical significance of the latter date. Also, identify the type of provisions that were brought into force immediately upon adoption and state the constitutional reason for their early implementation.
questions.model_answer_text: The date January 26 was chosen for the Constitution's full commencement due to its historical significance. It commemorated the 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) resolution passed at the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929; January 26, 1930, had been subsequently celebrated as the first Independence Day. While the full constitution came into force on this day, provisions related to 'citizenship' were implemented immediately on November 26, 1949. The constitutional reason for this was to enable persons displaced as a result of the partition of India to register themselves as Indian citizens without delay.

questions.question_text:
Read the passage compiled from your textbook and answer the questions that follow:

"The Indian Independence Act, 1947...recognised the existence of the Constituent Assembly of India. This legal sanction enabled the Constituent Assembly to function after India's independence. The Assembly became a sovereign body... At the Lahore Session... in December 1929, a resolution was passed which declared Poorna Swaraj... January 26, 1930 was fixed as the first Independence Day... January 26 was designated as the Republic Day... Dr. Rajendra Prasad... took over as the President of the Indian Union."

(i) What was the primary implication of the Constituent Assembly being declared a â€˜sovereign bodyâ€™? [1]
(ii) The Objectives Resolution declared that India would be a 'republic'. Explain how the choice of January 26th for the Constitution's enforcement and the change in the head of state after this date, collectively fulfilled this declaration. [2]
questions.model_answer_text:
(i) The primary implication of the Constituent Assembly becoming a â€˜sovereign bodyâ€™ was that it was supreme and fully independent, no longer subject to any limitations or authority imposed by the British Parliament. It had the ultimate power to draft the Constitution for India according to the will of its people.

(ii) The declaration of India as a 'republic' was fulfilled in two ways:
1.  **Symbolic Date:** The enforcement on January 26th linked the Constitution to the 'Poorna Swaraj' (Complete Independence) resolution of 1929. This date, designated as Republic Day, symbolized the final severance of ties with the British monarchy and the establishment of a government of the people.
2.  **Elected Head of State:** On this date, the post of the Governor-General (representing the Crown) was abolished and Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who was the President of the Constituent Assembly, took over as the first President of the Indian Union. A republic is characterized by an elected head of state, not a hereditary monarch or their representative.

criteria.description: Correctly explains that 'sovereign' meant the Assembly had supreme, independent authority, free from British control.
Correctly connects the date January 26th to its historical significance of the Poorna Swaraj resolution, symbolizing the republican ideal.
Correctly explains that the transition to an elected President from a Governor-General fulfilled the primary condition of a republic.

scoring_rules.notes: To earn the full 2 marks for part (ii), the answer must connect both the significance of the date AND the change in the head of state to the concept of a 'republic'. A partial answer explaining only one aspect will receive 1 mark.

questions.question_text:
Read the passage compiled from your textbook and answer the questions that follow:

"The 'Resolution' highlighted the objectives and laid down the 'national goals'... 2. The ideals of social, political and economic democracy would be guaranteed to all people... 4. The state would safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes... The text of the Constitution prepared by Babasaheb provided for... a system of reservation of jobs... for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes... [He also] Incorporated Directive Principles to ensure social and economic democracy..."

(i) Who proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' which set the national goals mentioned in the source? [1]
(ii) Based on the source, identify and explain two distinct constitutional mechanisms incorporated under Dr. Ambedkar's guidance to realise the goal of 'social and economic democracy' for 'minorities and backward classes'. [2]
questions.model_answer_text:
(i) The 'Objectives Resolution' was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru.

(ii) The two distinct constitutional mechanisms mentioned are:
1.  **System of Reservation:** This was a direct, affirmative action policy providing for the reservation of jobs in government services for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. This aimed to ensure their representation in administration and provide them with economic opportunities, thus promoting social and economic democracy.
2.  **Directive Principles of State Policy:** These are a set of guidelines and principles incorporated into the Constitution to direct the State (both Centre and State governments) to formulate policies and laws aimed at ensuring the welfare of the people and establishing social and economic democracy over time.

criteria.description: Correctly identifies Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru as the proposer of the Objectives Resolution.
Identifies the 'system of reservation' and briefly explains its purpose of providing jobs/representation to promote social/economic democracy for backward classes.
Identifies 'Directive Principles' and briefly explains their purpose as guidelines for the state to achieve social and economic democracy.

scoring_rules.notes: For part (ii), simply naming the two mechanisms is not sufficient for full marks. A brief explanation of how each mechanism aims to achieve 'social and economic democracy' is required for each point.

questions.question_text:
With reference to the framing of the Indian Constitution, answer the following questions:
(a) Define the term â€˜Constitutionâ€™. [2]
(b) Mention any three ways in which the Constitution of India is significant for governance. [3]
(c) Explain the difference between the date of adoption and the date of enforcement of the Indian Constitution, stating both dates clearly. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) A Constitution is a comprehensive document containing the set of rules that describe the rights and duties of its citizens and the manner in which the governance of a country is to be carried out.

(b) The Constitution of India is significant for governance in the following ways:
1.  It regulates the position and powers of the three organs of the government: the legislative, the executive, and the judiciary.
2.  It moderates the relationship between the government and the governed, protecting citizens' interests by restraining the government from taking arbitrary decisions.
3.  It lays down the framework to ensure smooth governance for the welfare of its citizens, distinguishing a democratic government from an absolute monarchy.

(c) The date of adoption is the day the Constituent Assembly passed and formally accepted the final draft of the Constitution. This was on November 26, 1949.
The date of enforcement is the day the Constitution as a whole came into effect, making India a Sovereign Democratic Republic. This was on January 26, 1950.
While the Constitution was adopted in 1949, the enforcement was delayed until 1950 to commemorate the historical significance of January 26, which was celebrated as Poorna Swaraj Day since 1930. Only a few provisions, like citizenship, came into force immediately upon adoption.

questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Constituent Assembly was set up under the proposals of the Cabinet Mission that arrived in India in 1946. Its members were to be elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies (Lower House only).

(b) The Constituent Assembly of undivided India consisted of 389 members. This included 292 members elected from the provinces, 93 members nominated by the rulers of the Princely States, three members from the Chief Commissioner Provinces, and one from the British.

(c) The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly, held on December 9, 1946, was presided over by Dr. Sachidananda Sinha, who was the oldest sitting member. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the permanent President of the Constituent Assembly on December 11, 1946.

questions.question_text:
The composition and functioning of the Constituent Assembly were significantly affected by the political developments of the time. In this context, answer the following questions:
(a) Why did the Muslim League boycott the Constituent Assembly? [2]
(b) How did the partition of India alter the membership of the Constituent Assembly? State the original and revised numbers. [3]
(c) Explain why the Constituent Assembly of India, even after the withdrawal of the Muslim League members, was considered 'truly national in character'. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Muslim League boycotted the Constituent Assembly because it was demanding the creation of a separate state for Muslims, called Pakistan, and did not wish to participate in framing a constitution for a united India.

(b) The partition of India led to the withdrawal of members representing the territories that went to Pakistan. As a result, the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India was reduced from the original 389 members to 299 members.

(c) The Constituent Assembly was considered 'truly national in character' because it gave representation to all shades of public opinion and various communities, even beyond the initial scope of the Cabinet Mission plan. The Congress leaders ensured that communities like the Anglo-Indians (represented by Frank Anthony), Indian Christians (represented by H.C. Mukherjee), Parsees (represented by Dr. H.P. Modi), Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes were included. Even after the League's boycott, members like Zafar Imam and Mohammad Saadullah represented the Muslim community. This diverse and wide-ranging membership ensured that the body reflected the pluralistic nature of India.

With reference to the Objectives Resolution, answer the following:
(a) Who proposed the â€˜Objectives Resolutionâ€™ and on what date was it introduced in the Constituent Assembly? [2]
(b) State any three â€˜national goalsâ€™ that were laid down by the Resolution. [3]
(c) Explain the overall significance of the â€˜Objectives Resolutionâ€™ in the process of constitution-making. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The â€˜Objectives Resolutionâ€™ was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru. It was introduced in the Constituent Assembly on December 13, 1946.

(b) Three â€˜national goalsâ€™ laid down by the Resolution were:
1.  To declare India as an independent, sovereign republic.
2.  To guarantee social, political, and economic democracy to all its people.
3.  To grant Fundamental Rights to all citizens and safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes.

(c) The â€˜Objectives Resolutionâ€™ was highly significant as it provided the philosophical foundation and guiding principles for the framers of the Constitution. It highlighted the core objectives and laid down the national goals that the new Constitution was meant to achieve. It defined the basic character of the future Indian state as a sovereign, democratic republic committed to justice, liberty, equality, and fraternity. The principles enshrined in this Resolution were later reflected in the Preamble, Fundamental Rights, and Directive Principles of State Policy of the Indian Constitution, thus shaping its very soul.

December 13 1946

questions.question_text:
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar played a pivotal role in drafting the Indian Constitution. In this context, answer the following:
(a) Which important committee of the Constituent Assembly was chaired by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar? When was it set up? [2]
(b) Mention two social rights or protections for which Dr. Ambedkar provided constitutional guarantees. [2]
(c) Dr. Ambedkar is rightly called one of the chief architects of the Indian Constitution. In this context, explain any three key principles he incorporated to build a strong, integrated, and welfare-oriented India. [6]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee. It was set up on August 29, 1947.

(b) Two social rights/protections for which Dr. Ambedkar provided constitutional guarantees were:
1. The abolition of untouchability.
2. A system of reservation of jobs in government services for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

(c) Three key principles incorporated by Dr. Ambedkar to build a strong, integrated, and welfare-oriented India are:
1.  **A strong Centre with single citizenship and a single judiciary:** He proposed a strong central government to maintain the territorial integrity and administrative discipline of the nation. This was complemented by provisions for a single citizenship and an integrated judicial system to foster a sense of unity among Indians.
2.  **Special safeguards for minorities and backward classes:** He ensured that the Constitution provided special protections and safeguards, including reservation, for minorities and socially and educationally backward classes to ensure they could become part of the national mainstream.
3.  **The Right to Constitutional Remedies:** To make the Fundamental Rights effective, he incorporated this right, which allows citizens to approach the judiciary if their rights are infringed by the state, thus making the judiciary the guardian of these rights.

August 29 1947

questions.question_text:
The adoption and implementation of the Constitution marked the birth of the Indian Republic. Regarding this process, answer the following:
(a) State the total time taken to frame the Constitution, and the number of Articles and Schedules it originally contained. [2]
(b) Briefly describe the process of â€˜Readingsâ€™ that the Draft Constitution underwent before it was finally passed. [3]
(c) Why did some clauses of the Constitution, such as those related to citizenship, come into force immediately on November 26, 1949? [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) It took nearly three years for the Constituent Assembly to frame the Constitution. At the time of its signing, it consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules.

(b) The Draft Constitution was discussed clause by clause in the Constituent Assembly. This began with the First Reading on November 4, 1948. This was followed by a detailed discussion in the Second Reading, which was completed on October 17, 1949. Finally, the Third and final Reading was completed on November 26, 1949, when the Constitution was passed.

(c) Certain clauses, particularly those relating to citizenship, came into force immediately on November 26, 1949, to address the urgent situation created by the partition of India. The partition had resulted in a massive displacement of people, with millions migrating across the newly formed borders. It was essential to immediately establish a legal framework to define who was an Indian citizen. This allowed persons displaced as a result of the partition to register themselves as Indian citizens without delay, thereby securing their legal status and rights in the new nation. The rest of the Constitution was enforced later on January 26, 1950.

criteria.keywords: nearly three years, 3 years
395 Articles, Eight Schedules, 8 Schedules
First Reading, November 1948
Second Reading, October 1949, clause by clause
Third Reading, final, November 26 1949

blocks.label: Part (c)

criteria.keywords: citizenship
partition, displaced persons, migration
enable persons to register as Indian citizens

blocks.scoring_rules: Award 1 mark for mentioning citizenship. Award 2 marks for explaining the context of partition and displacement. Award 2 marks for explaining the purpose of enabling registration.

questions.question_text:
The date for the commencement of the Indian Constitution, January 26, 1950, was chosen for its historical importance. In this context, answer the following:
(a) Which resolution was passed at the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929? [2]
(b) What was the significance of January 26, 1930, in the context of India's freedom struggle? [3]
(c) Explain why January 26 was chosen as the day for the Constitution to come into force, and how this day and India's actual Independence Day are now designated and celebrated. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) At the Lahore Session of the Congress held in December 1929, a resolution was passed which declared 'Poorna Swaraj' or Complete Independence as the objective of the Congress.

(b) Following the Poorna Swaraj resolution, January 26, 1930, was fixed as the first 'Independence Day', which was to be celebrated every year. It symbolised the Indian people's definitive declaration to strive for and achieve complete freedom from British rule.

(c) Although India achieved actual independence on August 15, 1947, the date January 26 was chosen for the commencement of the Constitution to honour its historical significance. It commemorated the 'Poorna Swaraj' declaration of 1929 and the first 'Independence Day' celebration of 1930. To preserve the importance of both historical dates, August 15 is celebrated as Independence Day, marking freedom from British rule, while January 26 was designated as Republic Day, marking the day India formally became a Sovereign Democratic Republic with its own constitution.

criteria.keywords: Lahore Session, December 1929
Poorna Swaraj, Complete Independence
fixed as first Independence Day
celebrated every year, symbolised struggle for freedom
chosen to honour historical significance, Poorna Swaraj day
August 15 designated as Independence Day
January 26 designated as Republic Day

questions.question_text:
With the commencement of the Constitution, India underwent a significant political transition. In this context, answer the following:
(a) Name India's first Indian Governor-General who succeeded Lord Mountbatten. [1]
(b) What dual role did the Constituent Assembly play after India's independence and until the first General Elections? [4]
(c) Describe the transition of the head of state from the British era to the new Republic, mentioning the key personality involved. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) C. Rajagopalachari was India's first Indian Governor-General.

(b) After India's independence on August 15, 1947, the Constituent Assembly became a sovereign body. It performed a dual role: first, as the body responsible for framing the Constitution, and second, as the provisional Parliament of India. It functioned as the central legislature, making laws for the country until the first General Elections were held in 1951-52 and a new Parliament was elected.

(c) Before the Constitution came into force, the head of state was the Governor-General, representing the British Monarch. Lord Mountbatten was the last British Governor-General, succeeded by C. Rajagopalachari. With the commencement of the Constitution on January 26, 1950, India became a Republic. The post of Governor-General was abolished and replaced by the President of India. Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who had been the President of the Constituent Assembly, took over as the first President of the Indian Union, becoming the new constitutional head of state.

criteria.keywords: C. Rajagopalachari

The Constituent Assembly was a microcosm of India itself, with representatives from various communities. Answer the following regarding its composition:

ii) The Parsees were represented by Dr. H.P. Modi.

(b) The Cabinet Mission plan had ensured representation for only three categories: the General category, Muslims, and Sikhs.

(c) The Congress leaders in the Constituent Assembly ensured a more inclusive representation by making sure that other communities beyond the three categories of the Cabinet Mission Plan were included. They actively brought in members from communities like the Anglo-Indians, Indian Christians, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes to make the Assembly truly national in character.
The Indian Christians were represented by Dr. H.C. Mukherjee.

questions.question_text:
The Indian Independence Act of 1947 had a profound impact on the legal status and functioning of the Constituent Assembly. In this regard, answer the following:
(a) What legal sanction did the Indian Independence Act, 1947 provide to the Constituent Assembly of India? [2]
(b) What did it mean for the Constituent Assembly to become a 'sovereign body'? [3]
(c) How did this new sovereign status enable the Assembly to carry out its work of drafting the Constitution effectively? Mention the key committee set up for this purpose. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Indian Independence Act, 1947, by creating the two independent states of India and Pakistan, formally recognised the existence of the Constituent Assembly of India and gave it legal sanction to function.

(b) For the Constituent Assembly to become a 'sovereign body' meant that it was no longer bound by the limitations or proposals of the British government, such as the Cabinet Mission Plan. It was fully independent and had the supreme power to frame any constitution it deemed fit for the country, without any external authority or control.

(c) As a sovereign body, the Constituent Assembly could function freely and structure its work as it saw fit. This enabled it to appoint various committees to deal with different aspects of the constitution-making process. The most important of these was the Drafting Committee, which was set up on August 29, 1947, under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. This committee was entrusted with the crucial task of preparing the actual draft of the Constitution based on the reports of other committees and the principles decided by the Assembly.

criteria.keywords: Indian Independence Act 1947, recognised existence, legal sanction
sovereign body, fully independent, supreme power
no longer bound by British limitations, free from external authority

Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, task of drafting

blocks.scoring_rules: Award 2 marks for explaining how sovereignty helped the Assembly's functioning. Award 2 marks for correctly identifying the Drafting Committee as the key committee. Award 1 mark for mentioning its chairman or specific task.

questions.question_text:
With reference to the nature and purpose of the Indian Constitution, answer the following:
(a) Define the term 'Constitution'. State the date on which the Constitution of India came into effect.
(b) Explain how a Constitution moderates the relationship between the government and the governed.
(c) How does the existence of a Constitution distinguish a democratic government from an absolute monarchy?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) A Constitution is a comprehensive document containing the set of rules that describe the rights and duties of its citizens and the manner in which the governance of a country is to be carried out. The Constitution of India came into effect on 26th January 1950.
(b) A Constitution moderates the relationship between the government and the governed by regulating the powers of the three organs of government (legislative, executive, judiciary) and protecting the interests of the citizens. It restrains the government from taking arbitrary decisions, thus ensuring a balance of power and safeguarding citizen rights.
(c) A democratic government is based on a Constitution which ensures smooth governance for the welfare of its citizens, guarantees rights, and defines the limits of governmental power. In contrast, an absolute monarchy or dictatorship is characterized by the arbitrary rule of a single person or group, without any constitutional checks, balances, or guaranteed rights for the people.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks are allocated based on the inclusion of key concepts mentioned in the criteria. Full marks for a part are awarded if all key concepts are adequately explained.

questions.question_text:
The framing of the Indian Constitution was a monumental task undertaken by the Constituent Assembly. In this context, answer the following:
(a) Which British mission proposed the setting up of a Constituent Assembly? How were its members to be chosen?
(b) What was the initial total strength of the Constituent Assembly of undivided India? State the number of members nominated by the Princely States.
(c) What was the consequence of the Muslim League's boycott of the Constituent Assembly on its total membership?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Cabinet Mission, which arrived in India in 1946, proposed the setting up of a Constituent Assembly. Its members were to be elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies (Lower House only).
(b) The initial total strength of the Constituent Assembly of undivided India was 389 members. Of these, 93 members were to be nominated by the rulers of the Princely States.
(c) The Muslim League boycotted the Constituent Assembly to press for their demand for a separate state of Pakistan. Consequently, the members representing the territories which went to Pakistan withdrew from the Assembly. This resulted in the reduction of the total membership from the original 389 to 299.

rubric.scoring_rules: Points awarded for each distinct and accurate piece of information as outlined in the criteria.

questions.question_text:
The Constituent Assembly's proceedings were pivotal in shaping modern India. Answer the following questions about its initial phase:
(a) When and where was the first sitting of the Constituent Assembly held? Who presided over this meeting?
(b) Who was elected as the permanent President of the Constituent Assembly, and on what date?
(c) Explain the significance of the 'Objectives Resolution'. Who proposed it?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held on December 9, 1946, at the present Central Hall of the Parliament. It was presided over by Dr. Sachidananda Sinha, who was the oldest sitting member.
(b) Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the permanent President of the Constituent Assembly on December 11, 1946.
(c) The 'Objectives Resolution' was significant as it highlighted the objectives of the constitution-making process and laid down the 'national goals'. It declared that free India would be a republic, guaranteeing social, political and economic democracy, Fundamental Rights, and safeguards for minorities and backward classes. It was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks are distributed for correctly identifying dates, names, locations, and key concepts.

questions.question_text:
The Constituent Assembly was a diverse body representing various communities of India. In this context, answer the following:
(a) How did the Cabinet Mission plan ensure representation in the Constituent Assembly? Name the three categories specified.
(b) Justify the statement that 'the Constituent Assembly was truly national in character' by mentioning how it went beyond the Cabinet Mission's plan.
(c) Name the representatives for the following communities: (i) Anglo-Indians, and (ii) Parsees.
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Cabinet Mission plan ensured representation by specifying three categories for members: the General category, Muslims, and Sikhs.
(b) The Constituent Assembly was 'truly national in character' because the Congress leaders ensured that communities beyond the three specified by the Cabinet Mission plan were also represented. This included getting representatives for communities like the Anglo-Indians, Indian Christians, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes, thus giving representation to all shades of public opinion.
(c) (i) The Anglo-Indians were represented by Mr. Frank Anthony and Mr. S.H. Prater. (ii) The Parsees were represented by Dr. H.P. Modi.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks awarded for identifying the specified categories, explaining the national character with examples, and naming the correct representatives.

questions.question_text:
With reference to the final stages of the constitution-making process, answer the following:
(a) Name the committee entrusted with the task of drafting the Constitution and its Chairman. When was this committee set up?
(b) Mention any two key principles that Dr. B.R. Ambedkar incorporated into the Constitution to ensure the liberty and dignity of the individual.
(c) How many Articles and Schedules did the Constitution of India contain at the time of its signing? How long did it take the Constituent Assembly to finally pass the Constitution?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Drafting Committee was entrusted with the task of drafting the Constitution. Its Chairman was Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. This committee was set up on August 29, 1947.
(b) Two key principles Dr. Ambedkar incorporated were: 1. Constitutional guarantees and protections for civil liberties like freedom of religion and the abolition of untouchability. 2. The Right to Constitutional Remedies to ensure that Fundamental Rights are not infringed by the government.
(c) At the time of its signing, the Constitution consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules. It took nearly three years for the Constituent Assembly to finally pass the Constitution.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks are awarded for accurate names, dates, numbers, and key constitutional principles.

questions.question_text:
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is regarded as one of the chief architects of the Indian Constitution. In this context, explain his contribution by focusing on the following:
(a) His efforts to provide special safeguards for minorities and backward classes.
(b) The provisions he incorporated to ensure national integrity and administrative discipline.
(c) The inclusion of principles aimed at establishing social and economic democracy.
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) Dr. Ambedkar provided for constitutional guarantees and protections for minorities and certain classes who are socially and educationally backward. This included a system of reservation of jobs in government services for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
(b) To maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline, he proposed a strong Centre. He also incorporated provisions for a single citizenship and a single judiciary, along with uniformity in fundamental laws, to integrate Indian society.
(c) To ensure social and economic democracy and the welfare of the people of India, Dr. Ambedkar incorporated the Directive Principles of State Policy in the Constitution.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks awarded for explaining Dr. Ambedkar's specific contributions related to safeguards, national unity, and socio-economic principles.

questions.question_text:
The adoption and implementation of the Constitution marked the birth of the Indian Republic. Answer the following:
(a) On what date was the Constitution adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly? How many members appended their signatures to the final document?
(b) Explain why some clauses of the Constitution came into force immediately after its signing, while the rest came into force later.
(c) What institutional changes took place with the commencement of the Constitution on January 26, 1950, regarding the roles of the Governor-General, the Constituent Assembly, and the President?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949. On this day, 284 members who were present appended their signatures to the Constitution.
(b) Only the clauses relating to citizenship and some others came into force immediately. This was done to enable persons displaced as a result of the partition of India to register themselves as Indian citizens. The Constitution as a whole came into force later, on January 26, 1950.
(c) With the commencement of the Constitution, C. Rajagopalachari, who had replaced Lord Mountbatten as Governor-General, completed his term. The Constituent Assembly became the provisional parliament until the first General Elections. Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who was the President of the Constituent Assembly, took over as the first President of the Indian Union.

rubric.scoring_rules: Points awarded for correct dates, numbers, reasons for partial implementation, and description of institutional transitions.

questions.question_text:
The date January 26 was specifically chosen for the enforcement of the Constitution due to its historical importance. With regard to this, answer the following:
(a) Which session of the Congress passed the resolution for 'Poorna Swaraj', and when was it held?
(b) What was the objective declared in the 'Poorna Swaraj' resolution? Which date was fixed as the first 'Independence Day'?
(c) How did the significance of January 26 change after India achieved actual independence on August 15, 1947?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The resolution for 'Poorna Swaraj' or Complete Independence was passed at the Lahore Session of the Congress, which was held in December 1929.
(b) The objective declared in the resolution was to achieve 'Poorna Swaraj' or Complete Independence from British rule. The date fixed to be celebrated as the first 'Independence Day' was January 26, 1930.
(c) After India achieved independence, August 15 became the official Independence Day. To honour the historical significance of January 26, which had been celebrated as Independence Day from 1930 to 1947, this date was designated as Republic Day, the day the Constitution came into full force.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks awarded for identifying the correct historical events, dates, resolutions, and the transition of significance for Jan 26.

questions.question_text:
The drafting of the Constitution was a meticulous and sovereign process. In this context, answer the following:
(a) What legal sanction enabled the Constituent Assembly to function as a sovereign body after August 15, 1947?
(b) Describe the process of 'Readings' that the Draft Constitution underwent in the Constituent Assembly.
(c) How did Dr. B.R. Ambedkar ensure that the Constitution would be workable and flexible?
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Indian Independence Act, 1947, gave legal sanction to the Constituent Assembly. This Act recognised its existence and enabled it to function as a sovereign body after India's independence.
(b) After the draft was prepared, it was discussed clause by clause in the Constituent Assembly starting from November 4, 1948. This was followed by the second Reading, completed on October 17, 1949, and then the third and final Reading, which was completed on November 26, 1949.
(c) Dr. Ambedkar made the Indian Constitution workable, flexible, and strong enough to hold the country together in both peace and in war. The flexibility comes from the process of Amendment, which allows the Constitution to be altered according to changing needs, preventing it from being too rigid.

rubric.scoring_rules: Full marks for correctly identifying the Act, describing the legislative process, and explaining the concept of a flexible constitution as per Dr. Ambedkar's vision.

questions.question_text:
The 'Objectives Resolution' served as a guiding light for the Constituent Assembly. Answer the following questions based on its key principles:
(a) On what date was the 'Objectives Resolution' proposed and on what date was it finally passed?
(b) State any two political or civil ideals guaranteed to the people of India by the Resolution.
(c) Mention two provisions in the Resolution aimed at social justice and protection of vulnerable sections of society.
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The 'Objectives Resolution' was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946. It was passed by the Constituent Assembly on January 22, 1947.
(b) Two political/civil ideals guaranteed were: 1. Free India will be nothing but a 'republic'. 2. The republic would grant 'Fundamental Rights' to all citizens.
(c) Two provisions aimed at social justice were: 1. The ideals of social and economic democracy would be guaranteed to all people. 2. The state would safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes.

rubric.scoring_rules: Marks are awarded for providing the correct dates and clearly stating the distinct principles of the Objectives Resolution as requested.

questions.question_text:
With reference to the framing of the Indian Constitution, answer the following questions:
(a) Who was elected as the President of the Constituent Assembly? On what date was the first sitting of the Assembly held? [2]
(b) State any three key 'national goals' that were laid down by the 'Objectives Resolution'. [3]
(c) Explain the contribution of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar to the Indian Constitution with reference to any five principles that he incorporated. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the President of the Constituent Assembly on December 11, 1946. The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held on December 9, 1946.

(b) The three key 'national goals' laid down by the 'Objectives Resolution' were:
1. Free India will be a 'republic'.
2. The ideals of social, political and economic democracy would be guaranteed to all people.
3. The republic would grant Fundamental Rights to its citizens. 
(An alternative point: The state would safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes.)

(c) Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, as the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, made significant contributions to the Indian Constitution. Five key principles he incorporated are:
1. **Workable and Flexible Constitution:** He ensured the Constitution was strong enough to hold the country together in both peacetime and wartime, while also being adaptable.
2. **Safeguards for Minorities:** He provided for constitutional guarantees and special safeguards for minorities and socially/educationally backward classes, including the system of reservation of jobs for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
3. **Right to Constitutional Remedies:** This was included to ensure that the Fundamental Rights of individuals are protected and cannot be arbitrarily infringed upon by the Centre or State governments.
4. **National Unity and a Strong Centre:** He promoted national integration through principles like a single citizenship, a single judiciary, and a strong central government to maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline.
5. **Social and Economic Democracy:** He incorporated the Directive Principles of State Policy to guide the state in ensuring the welfare of the people and establishing a just social and economic order.

blocks.label: Part (a)
blocks.scoring_rules: 1 mark for correctly identifying the President. 1 mark for the correct date of the first sitting.

blocks.label: Part (b)
blocks.scoring_rules: Award 1 mark for each of any three valid national goals mentioned in the Objectives Resolution.

blocks.label: Part (c)
blocks.scoring_rules: Award 1 mark for each of any five valid contributions or principles incorporated by Dr. Ambedkar, with a brief explanation.

questions.question_text:
With reference to the nature and purpose of the Indian Constitution, answer the following questions:
(a) Define the term 'Constitution'. State the date of its adoption and the date of its enforcement. [3]
(b) Explain how a Constitution moderates the relationship between the government and the governed, and how it distinguishes a democratic government from a dictatorship. [3]
(c) Describe the three primary functions of a Constitution with respect to the organs of the government and the rights of citizens, as mentioned in the text. [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) A 'Constitution' is a comprehensive document containing the set of rules describing the rights and duties of its citizens and the manner of governance. It was adopted on November 26, 1949, and came into force on January 26, 1950.

(b) A Constitution moderates relations by protecting the interests of citizens and restraining the government from taking arbitrary decisions. The principles of a Constitution, which establish a system of rights and limited government power, distinguish a constitutional or democratic government from an absolute monarchy or dictatorship where power is unlimited and citizens' rights are not guaranteed.

(c) The three primary functions are: 1. It regulates the position and powers of the three organs of the governmentâ€”the legislative, the executive, and the judiciary, and states how they are inter-related. 2. It protects the interests of the citizens by restraining the government from arbitrary actions. 3. It describes the rights and duties of its citizens, aiming to ensure smooth governance for their welfare.

questions.question_text:
The framing of the Indian Constitution was a monumental task undertaken by the Constituent Assembly. In this context, answer the following:
(a) Under which plan was the Constituent Assembly established? State its initial total strength and the method by which its members were chosen from Provincial Legislative Assemblies and Princely States. [3]
(b) Explain the impact of the Muslim League's boycott and the subsequent partition of India on the membership of the Constituent Assembly. State the original and revised membership numbers. [3]
(c) Who was elected as the first President of the Constituent Assembly? On what date did the Assembly become a sovereign body, and what legal sanction enabled this status? How did its role change after this point until 1952? [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Constituent Assembly was established under the proposals of the Cabinet Mission of 1946. Its initial total strength was 389 members. Members from the Provincial Legislative Assemblies were elected indirectly (by the Lower House only), while representatives from the Princely States were nominated by their respective rulers.

(b) The Muslim League boycotted the Constituent Assembly to demand Pakistan. Consequently, after partition, members representing territories that went to Pakistan withdrew from the Assembly. This reduced the membership of the Constituent Assembly of India from the original 389 to 299.

(c) Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected President of the Constituent Assembly on December 11, 1946. The Assembly became a sovereign body after India's independence. This was enabled by the legal sanction of the Indian Independence Act, 1947. After this, the Constituent Assembly also functioned as the provisional parliament of India until the first General Elections were held in 1951â€“52.

questions.question_text:
The 'Objectives Resolution' laid the philosophical foundation of the Indian Constitution. With regard to this resolution, answer the following:
(a) Who proposed the 'Objectives Resolution' and on what date? When was it finally passed by the Constituent Assembly? [3]
(b) State the four 'national goals' or key objectives highlighted in the Resolution. [4]
(c) How did the principles of the 'Objectives Resolution' later find expression in the contributions of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, particularly concerning Fundamental Rights and the welfare of minorities? [3]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The 'Objectives Resolution' was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946. It was passed by the Constituent Assembly on January 22, 1947.

(b) The four key objectives were: 1. Free India will be nothing but a 'republic'. 2. The ideals of social, political and economic democracy would be guaranteed to all people. 3. The republic would grant Fundamental Rights to citizens. 4. The state would safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes.

(c) The principles of the 'Objectives Resolution' directly influenced Dr. Ambedkar's work. The goal of granting Fundamental Rights was realized through his incorporation of the Right to Constitutional Remedies to ensure these rights were not infringed. The goal of safeguarding minorities and backward classes was addressed through his provision of special safeguards and a system of reservation for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

questions.question_text:
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is rightly called one of the chief architects of the Indian Constitution. Elaborate on his contributions by answering the following:
(a) As the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, what was Dr. Ambedkar's primary responsibility? When was this committee set up? [2]
(b) Dr. Ambedkar incorporated several principles to forge a strong and unified nation. Explain his contributions with respect to (i) the nature of the Constitution's framework, (ii) the structure of the Indian federation, and (iii) the incorporation of Directive Principles. [4]
(c) In his efforts to guarantee civil liberties and social justice, describe the specific constitutional provisions Dr. Ambedkar championed for (i) the protection of Fundamental Rights, (ii) the abolition of a major social evil, and (iii) the upliftment of Scheduled Castes and Tribes. [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) As the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, Dr. Ambedkar's primary responsibility was to draft the Constitution. The Drafting Committee was set up on August 29, 1947.

(b) (i) He made the Constitution workable, flexible, and strong enough to hold the country together in both peace and war. (ii) He proposed a strong Centre, single citizenship, and a single judiciary to integrate Indian society and maintain territorial integrity. (iii) He incorporated Directive Principles to ensure social and economic democracy and the welfare of the people.

(c) (i) He incorporated the Right to Constitutional Remedies to ensure Fundamental Rights were not infringed by the government. (ii) He included provisions for the abolition of untouchability. (iii) He provided for a system of reservation of jobs in government services for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, along with other special safeguards for socially and educationally backward classes.

questions.question_text:
The Constituent Assembly was designed to be truly 'national in character'. Justify this statement with reference to its diverse composition.
(a) The Cabinet Mission Plan initially ensured representation for only three categories. Name them. How did the Congress leaders ensure a broader representation? [3]
(b) Name the two members who represented the Anglo-Indian community and the two members who represented the Indian Christian community. [2]
(c) Despite the Muslim League's boycott, the Muslim community was still represented. Name the two Muslim members mentioned. Additionally, identify the representatives for the Parsees and the Sikhs, citing one name for each community. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Cabinet Mission plan ensured representation for only the General category, Muslims, and Sikhs. The Congress leaders ensured broader representation by making sure that other communities like Anglo-Indians, Indian Christians, Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes also got representation.

(b) The Anglo-Indians were represented by Mr. Frank Anthony and Mr. S.H. Prater. The Indian Christians were represented by Dr. H.C. Mukherjee and Joseph D'souza.

(c) The two Muslim members were Zafar Imam and Mohammad Saadullah. The Parsees were represented by Dr. H.P. Modi. The Sikhs were represented by Sardar Hukum Singh and Ujjal Singh (any one name is sufficient for Sikhs).

questions.question_text:
The finalisation of the Constitution was a meticulous and time-consuming process. Regarding this legislative journey, answer the following:
(a) The Draft Constitution underwent three 'Readings'. State the start date of the first clause-by-clause discussion and the completion dates for the second and third readings. [3]
(b) How much time did the Constituent Assembly take to finally pass the Constitution? At the time of its signing, how many Articles and Schedules did the document contain? [3]
(c) After the signing on November 26, 1949, did the entire Constitution come into force immediately? Explain with reference to the provisions that were enforced right away and the reason for their immediate implementation. [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The clause-by-clause discussion of the Draft began on November 4, 1948. The second Reading was completed on October 17, 1949. The third and final Reading was completed on November 26, 1949.

(b) It took nearly three years for the Constituent Assembly to finally pass the Constitution. At the time of its signing, the Constitution consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules.

(c) No, the entire Constitution did not come into force immediately. Only the clauses relating to citizenship and some other provisions came into force immediately after signing. This was done specifically to enable persons who were displaced as a result of the partition to register themselves as Indian citizens.

keywords: entire Constitution did not come into force

questions.question_text:
The period between the adoption and the full enforcement of the Constitution was one of significant political transition. With respect to this period, answer the following:
(a) Distinguish between the 'adoption' and the 'enforcement' of the Constitution by citing the respective dates. [2]
(b) After Lord Mountbatten, who became the Governor-General of India? What role did the Constituent Assembly assume during this interim period? [3]
(c) Who took over as the first President of the Indian Union upon the Constitution's commencement? What was his preceding role in the constitution-making body? How many members actually signed the Constitution on November 26, 1949? [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Constitution was 'adopted and passed' by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949. It 'came into force' or was 'enforced' as a whole on January 26, 1950.

(b) After Lord Mountbatten, C. Rajagopalachari became the Governor-General. During this interim period, the Constituent Assembly became the provisional parliament until the new General Elections were held in 1951â€“52.

(c) Dr. Rajendra Prasad took over as the first President of the Indian Union. His preceding role was as the President of the Constituent Assembly. On November 26, 1949, 284 members were actually present and appended their signatures to the Constitution.

questions.question_text:
The date January 26 was specifically chosen for the commencement of the Constitution due to its historical importance in the freedom struggle. Elaborate on this significance.
(a) Which session of the Congress passed the resolution for 'Poorna Swaraj', and in which year was it held? [2]
(b) What was the objective declared in this resolution? Which date was consequently fixed as the 'first Independence Day'? [3]
(c) Explain the transition of how January 26, once celebrated as Independence Day, came to be designated as Republic Day after India achieved actual independence. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The resolution for 'Poorna Swaraj' was passed at the Lahore Session of the Congress, held in December 1929.

(b) The objective declared was 'Poorna Swaraj' or Complete Independence. The date fixed as the first Independence Day was January 26, 1930.

(c) From 1930 up to 1947, January 26 was celebrated every year as Independence Day in line with the Lahore resolution. However, when India achieved actual independence, August 15, 1947, became the official Independence Day. To honour the historical significance of January 26 and the pledge of Poorna Swaraj, the framers of the Constitution chose this date for its full enforcement. Consequently, January 26 was designated as the Republic Day, marking the day India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic.

questions.question_text:
With reference to the framing of the Indian Constitution, answer the following questions:
(a) Explain the proposal of the Cabinet Mission of 1946 that led to the formation of the Constituent Assembly. Describe the method of election for its members. [3]
(b) The Constituent Assembly was described as being 'truly national in character'. Justify this statement by analysing its diverse composition. [3]
(c) What was the 'Objectives Resolution'? Discuss any four of its key objectives that laid down the 'national goals' for the future Indian Republic. [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Cabinet Mission, which arrived in India in 1946, put forward a proposal to set up a Constituent Assembly to frame the Constitution for India. The members of this Assembly were to be elected indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies (Lower House only). Additionally, the Princely States were to be represented by members nominated by their respective rulers. The elections to the Provincial Assembly were completed by July 1946, leading to the formation of the Constituent Assembly.

(b) The statement that the Constituent Assembly was 'truly national in character' is justified because it gave representation to all shades of public opinion and communities, going beyond the three categories (General, Muslims, Sikhs) specified by the Cabinet Mission plan. Congress leaders ensured that other communities were represented. For example:
1. The Anglo-Indians were represented by Mr. Frank Anthony and Mr. S.H. Prater.
2. The Indian Christians were represented by Dr. H.C. Mukherjee and Joseph D'souza.
3. The Parsees were represented by Dr. H.P. Modi.
4. Even after the Muslim League's boycott, the Muslim community was represented by members like Zafar Imam and Mohammad Saadullah.
5. The Sikhs were represented by Sardar Hukum Singh and Ujjal Singh.
This broad-based representation ensured that the interests and perspectives of various sections of Indian society were considered.

(c) The 'Objectives Resolution' was a resolution proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946, which highlighted the objectives of the Constitution and laid down the 'national goals' for independent India. The four key objectives were:
1. **Republic:** It declared that free India would be a republic, meaning the head of the state would be an elected person and not a hereditary monarch.
2. **Socio-economic and political justice:** It aimed to guarantee the ideals of social, political, and economic democracy for all citizens.
3. **Fundamental Rights:** The resolution proposed that the republic would grant and guarantee Fundamental Rights to all its citizens, ensuring individual liberty and freedom.
4. **Safeguards for Minorities:** It resolved that the state would provide adequate safeguards for the rights and interests of minorities, backward classes, and tribal areas.

criteria.keywords: Cabinet Mission 1946 proposal set up Constituent Assembly
members elected indirectly Provincial Legislative Assemblies
Princely States represented nominated by rulers
Justifies 'truly national character' by mentioning representation for all shades of public opinion or communities beyond the main three.
Names at least one specific community and its representative (e.g., Anglo-Indians by Frank Anthony, Parsees by H.P. Modi).
Names a second specific community and its representative, demonstrating breadth of knowledge (e.g., Indian Christians by H.C. Mukherjee, Sikhs by Sardar Hukum Singh).

blocks.label: Part (c)

criteria.keywords: Defines Objectives Resolution as proposed by Nehru, highlighting objectives/national goals.
States objective of India being a 'republic'.
States objective of guaranteeing social, political, and economic democracy.
States objective of granting Fundamental Rights to citizens OR safeguarding rights of minorities/backward classes.

blocks.scoring_rules: Award one mark for defining the resolution and one mark for each of any three objectives mentioned.

questions.question_text:
The finalisation and implementation of the Indian Constitution was a monumental task. In this context, answer the following:
(a) Who was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee? Analyse any two of his significant contributions that shaped the principles of the Constitution. [3]
(b) Explain the process of 'Readings' that the Draft Constitution went through in the Constituent Assembly. What was the total time taken to complete this process? [3]
(c) Differentiate between the 'adoption' and the 'enforcement' of the Constitution, stating the respective dates. Explain the historical significance of January 26 being chosen as the date of enforcement. [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(a) The Chairman of the Drafting Committee was Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. His two significant contributions that shaped the principles of the Constitution are:
1. **Incorporation of Safeguards for Minorities and Weaker Sections:** Dr. Ambedkar ensured the text of the Constitution provided for constitutional guarantees and protections for minorities and certain classes who are socially and educationally backward. This included a system of reservation of jobs in government services for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and the abolition of untouchability.
2. **Ensuring Fundamental Rights and Constitutional Remedies:** He incorporated the 'Right to Constitutional Remedies' to ensure that the Fundamental Rights of individuals are not infringed upon by the Centre or State governments. This provision makes the Fundamental Rights justiciable and is crucial for protecting civil liberties.

(b) After the draft was prepared, it was thoroughly discussed in the Constituent Assembly through a process involving three readings:
1. **First Reading:** The Draft was introduced in the Assembly in November 1948 and was discussed clause by clause.
2. **Second Reading:** This was a more detailed examination, which was completed on October 17, 1949.
3. **Third and Final Reading:** This reading was completed on November 26, 1949, after which the Constitution was passed and adopted.
The entire process for the Constituent Assembly to finally pass the Constitution took nearly three years (specifically, 2 years, 11 months and 18 days, though the text states 'nearly three years').

(c) The difference between 'adoption' and 'enforcement' is as follows:
*   **Adoption:** The Constitution was 'adopted and passed' by the Constituent Assembly on **November 26, 1949**. This signifies the legal finalisation and acceptance of the document by the framers.
*   **Enforcement:** The Constitution as a whole 'came into force' on **January 26, 1950**. This is the date from which its provisions became legally binding for the governance of the country.

The historical significance of choosing January 26 is that at the Lahore Session of the Congress in December 1929, a resolution was passed declaring **Poorna Swaraj** (Complete Independence) as the objective. Subsequently, **January 26, 1930**, was celebrated as the first 'Independence Day'. To honour this historic day, January 26 was chosen as the 'Republic Day' when the Constitution came into force, even though India became independent on August 15, 1947.

blocks.label: Part (a)

criteria.keywords: Chairman Drafting Committee Dr. B.R. Ambedkar Babasaheb
Contribution: special safeguards for minorities backward classes SC/ST reservations abolition of untouchability.
Contribution: Right to Constitutional Remedies ensure Fundamental Rights single citizenship strong Centre Directive Principles.

blocks.scoring_rules: Award 1 mark for naming the Chairman and 1 mark for each of the two distinct contributions explained.

Provides some details of the readings, such as the period (Nov 1948 - Nov 1949).
States the total time taken was nearly three years.

questions.question_text: The Indian Independence Act of 1947 conferred upon the Constituent Assembly a unique dual character, transforming its legal status and scope of work. Analyze this statement by explaining the two distinct sovereign functions the Assembly performed post-August 1947. Furthermore, deduce how the principle of a 'strong Centre', advocated by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, was a logical constitutional outcome given the Assembly's experience in its legislative capacity during the tumultuous post-partition period.
questions.model_answer_text:
The statement is accurate. Post-August 15, 1947, the Indian Independence Act transformed the Constituent Assembly into a sovereign body, empowering it to perform a dual role:

1.  **Constituent Function:** Its primary and original mandate was to frame the Constitution for a free India. As a sovereign body, free from the constraints of the Cabinet Mission plan, it could draft a constitution reflecting the nation's own ideals. This is evidenced by the setting up of the Drafting Committee on August 29, 1947, to create the foundational legal text.

2.  **Legislative Function:** It also functioned as the first, provisional Parliament of India. The text states, "The Constituent Assembly became the provisional parliament until the new General Elections were held in 1951â€“52." In this capacity, it governed the country, made ordinary laws, and managed the administration during the critical transition period.

**Deductive Link to 'Strong Centre':**
Dr. Ambedkar's advocacy for a 'strong Centre' can be deduced as a response to the challenges faced by the Assembly in its legislative capacity. The immediate aftermath of independence and partition brought immense administrative and integration challenges, including managing displaced populations and unifying the nation. Governing the country as a provisional parliament would have highlighted the dangers of fragmentation and the need for administrative discipline and territorial integrity. Therefore, incorporating principles like a strong Centre, single citizenship, and a single judiciary into the constitution was a logical step to ensure the stability and unity of the new republic, a lesson learned firsthand from the practical experience of governance.

criteria.keywords: Constituent function, framing the constitution, drafting the constitution
Legislative function, provisional parliament, governing the country, making laws
Connects Assembly's legislative experience, post-partition challenges, managing administration, integration of states
Logically links these challenges to the need for a strong centre, territorial integrity, administrative discipline, unity, stability as advocated by Dr. Ambedkar

rubric.scoring_rules: Full marks (4) for correctly identifying both functions with evidence/context from the text AND providing a logical, deductive link between the Assembly's governance experience and the constitutional principle of a strong Centre. Partial marks are awarded for identifying functions without the deductive link, or for a weak/unclear link.

questions.question_text:
The provided text establishes that the Constituent Assembly was "truly national in character" and that the Objectives Resolution laid down specific "national goals". Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is credited as one of the chief "architects of the Constitution".

Analyse how the principles and provisions Dr. Ambedkar incorporated into the Constitution directly addressed the national goals set by the Objectives Resolution and reflected the aspirations of the diverse communities represented in the Constituent Assembly. Support your analysis with three distinct examples, linking a specific constitutional principle/provision to a goal from the Objectives Resolution and the interests of the represented communities.
questions.model_answer_text:
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, in his role as the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, systematically translated the abstract ideals of the Objectives Resolution and the inclusive vision of the Constituent Assembly into concrete, workable constitutional mechanisms. This is evident through the following examples:

1.  **Safeguarding Minorities and Backward Classes:** The Objectives Resolution explicitly mandated that the state would "safeguard the rights of minorities and backward classes." The Constituent Assembly's 'national character' was demonstrated by the presence of representatives from various communities like Anglo-Indians (Mr. Frank Anthony), Parsees (Dr. H.P. Modi), and Scheduled Castes. Dr. Ambedkar directly addressed this national goal by incorporating "special safeguards" for minorities and a system of "reservation of jobs in the government services for members of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes," thereby giving constitutional force to the aspirations of these represented groups.

2.  **Guaranteeing Enforceable Fundamental Rights:** The Objectives Resolution declared that the republic would grant "Fundamental Rights" to all citizens. Dr. Ambedkar ensured this was not a mere declaration. He architected the crucial "Right to Constitutional Remedies," a provision he considered the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution. This right empowers citizens to approach the judiciary if their rights are infringed, making the guarantee of rights enforceable and not just a promise, thus fulfilling a core objective in a robust manner.

3.  **Ensuring Socio-Economic Democracy:** The Objectives Resolution aimed to secure "social, political and economic democracy" for all people. To achieve the social and economic dimensions of this goal, Dr. Ambedkar incorporated the "Directive Principles of State Policy." These principles, while not judicially enforceable, are fundamental guidelines for governance, aiming to establish a welfare state and ensure social and economic justice. This provision directly translates the abstract ideal of economic democracy into a constitutional objective for the state to pursue for the welfare of all citizens.

keywords: analysis explicitly links the three components (CA composition, Objectives Resolution, Ambedkar's provisions) in a coherent argument for each example
demonstrates deductive reasoning by showing how provisions fulfilled the goals

rubric.scoring_rules: Award 1 mark for each of the three distinct and well-explained examples that correctly link an Objective Resolution goal to a constitutional provision by Dr. Ambedkar. Award a final 1 mark for the overall quality of analysis, demonstrating a clear understanding of the deductive link between the Assembly's vision, its stated goals, and the final constitutional architecture.

questions.question_text:
The image shows the members of the Constituent Assembly of India during one of its sessions. The presence of members such as Mr. Frank Anthony, Dr. H.C. Mookerjee, and Sardar Hukam Singh in this body demonstrates which key characteristic of the Assembly?

questions.model_answer_text:

Mookerjee), and Sikhs (represented by Sardar Hukam Singh) received representation. This diverse composition made the Assembly 'truly national in character'.

choices.label: Its members were all directly elected by universal adult franchise.

questions.question_text:
The image displays the final page of the original Constitution of India, showing the signatures of the members. The date mentioned above the signatures, November 26, 1949, holds a specific constitutional significance. What event took place on this day?

(a) The Constitution came into full force, and India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic.
(b) The Drafting Committee under Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was formally established.
(c) The Constituent Assembly passed and adopted the Constitution, completing its final reading.
(d) The Objectives Resolution was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru, laying down national goals.
questions.model_answer_text:
(c) The Constituent Assembly passed and adopted the Constitution, completing its final reading.
The text clearly states that the 'third and the final Reading' was completed on November 26, 1949, and that the 'Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949'. The Constitution came into force later, on January 26, 1950.

choices.label: The Constitution came into full force, and India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic.
The Drafting Committee under Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was formally established.
The Constituent Assembly passed and adopted the Constitution, completing its final reading.
The Objectives Resolution was proposed by Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru, laying down national goals.

questions.question_text:
The photograph shows a group of eminent jurists and leaders. This specific group was constituted by the Constituent Assembly on August 29, 1947. What was the primary institutional mandate of this body, known as the Drafting Committee?

(a) To preside over the sessions of the Constituent Assembly.
(b) To negotiate the terms of independence with the British.
(c) To pass the 'Objectives Resolution' that defined the national goals.
(d) To prepare the formal text of the Constitution for consideration by the Assembly.
questions.model_answer_text:
(d) To prepare the formal text of the Constitution for consideration by the Assembly.
The text specifies that the Drafting Committee, under the Chairmanship of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, was set up on August 29, 1947, and 'was entrusted with the task of drafting the Constitution'. The other options refer to functions performed by other individuals or the Assembly as a whole, not this specific committee.

choices.label: To preside over the sessions of the Constituent Assembly.
To negotiate the terms of independence with the British.
To pass the 'Objectives Resolution' that defined the national goals.
