questions.question_text:
The image shows a pivotal moment in the framing of the Indian Constitution, with the Chairman of the Drafting Committee addressing the Constituent Assembly. Based on your knowledge of the constitutional process and the principles championed by this individual, which of the following sets of provisions were most central to his vision for ensuring both national unity and social justice in the document he presented?

(a) A decentralised federal structure with significant provincial autonomy, dual citizenship, and separate electorates for minorities.
(b) A strong central government, a single integrated judiciary, and constitutional safeguards including reservations for minorities and backward classes.
(c) The immediate implementation of a Uniform Civil Code, making Hindi the sole official language, and a presidential system of government.
(d) The supremacy of the legislature over the judiciary, reservation in private sector employment, and the right to property as an absolute fundamental right.
questions.model_answer_text: The correct option is (b). The figure shown is Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, the Chairman of the Drafting Committee. He was a key architect of the Constitution who advocated for a strong central government and a single, integrated judicial system to ensure national unity and administrative discipline. Simultaneously, to promote social and economic democracy, he was instrumental in incorporating special constitutional safeguards and a system of reservation for minorities, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes. The other options contain provisions that contradict his known positions or the final form of the Constitution.

options: A decentralised federal structure with significant provincial autonomy, dual citizenship, and separate electorates for minorities.
A strong central government, a single integrated judiciary, and constitutional safeguards including reservations for minorities and backward classes.
The immediate implementation of a Uniform Civil Code, making Hindi the sole official language, and a presidential system of government.
The supremacy of the legislature over the judiciary, reservation in private sector employment, and the right to property as an absolute fundamental right.

questions.question_text:
Study the picture shown. 
(i) Identify the person shown in the picture and the document he is signing. [2]
(ii) Name the body that framed this document and state the official position held by this individual within it. How many members ultimately signed the document, and what did it consist of in terms of Articles and Schedules at the time of its signing? [3]
(iii) The Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949, but came into force on January 26, 1950. Explain the significance of both these dates and describe the change in the constitutional role of the person identified after the latter date. [5]
questions.model_answer_text:
(i) The person shown is Dr. Rajendra Prasad. He is signing the Constitution of India.

(ii) The body that framed this document was the Constituent Assembly. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the President of the Constituent Assembly. 284 members appended their signatures to the Constitution as finally passed. At the time of its signing, the Constitution consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules.

(iii) November 26, 1949, is the date the Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly. On this date, only some clauses, mainly relating to citizenship, came into force immediately. January 26, 1950, is the date the Constitution as a whole came into force, and India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic. This date was chosen for its historical importance, as it was celebrated as Poorna Swaraj Day since 1930. After this date, Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who was the President of the Constituent Assembly, took over as the first President of the Indian Union.

questions.question_text:

(i) Identify the individual shown signing the document. State his official designation within the body responsible for framing this document. [2]

questions.model_answer_text:
(i) The individual shown is Dr. Rajendra Prasad. His official designation was the President of the Constituent Assembly.
(ii) The Indian Independence Act of 1947 recognised the existence of the Constituent Assembly of India, providing it with legal sanction. This enabled the Assembly to function as a sovereign body, with the authority to draft the Constitution for an independent India. On November 26, 1949, a total of 284 members were present and appended their signatures to the finally passed Constitution.
(iii) Following the adoption of the Constitution, the following institutional changes occurred:
1. The Constituent Assembly became the provisional Parliament of India, serving as the central legislature until the first General Elections were held in 1951â€“52.
2. The post of Governor-General, last held by C. Rajagopalachari, was abolished.
3. Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who had presided over the Constituent Assembly, took over as the first President of the Indian Union when the Constitution came into full effect on January 26, 1950.

(i) Identify the individual shown and the document he is signing. State his formal position within the sovereign body responsible for creating this document. [3]
(ii) Describe the context of this event. Mention the specific date on which the document was adopted, the number of members who ultimately appended their signatures, and the total duration this body took to complete its work. [3]
(iii) Explain the legal and institutional consequences that followed this act of signing. In your answer, refer to the structure of the document at the time of its signing, the transition of the Constituent Assembly, and the subsequent role of the person identified in (i). [4]
questions.model_answer_text:
(i) The individual shown is Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who is signing the Constitution of India. His formal position was the President of the Constituent Assembly.

(ii) The context of the event is the final adoption of the Constitution of India after its third reading. The document was formally adopted and passed on November 26, 1949. On this day, 284 members who were actually present appended their signatures to the Constitution. The Constituent Assembly took nearly three years to complete its task of framing the Constitution.

(iii) The immediate legal consequence was that clauses related to citizenship came into force at once. The eventual consequence was the full enforcement of the Constitution on January 26, 1950. The document being signed consisted of 395 Articles and Eight Schedules. Institutionally, the Constituent Assembly transitioned to become the provisional parliament of India until the General Elections of 1951â€“52. Following the Constitution's enforcement, Dr. Rajendra Prasad transitioned from being the President of the Constituent Assembly to become the first President of the Indian Union.
